ARTICLE III. - ANIMAL PROTECTION AND CONTROL FOOTNOTE(S): --- (3) --- State Law reference— Authority of municipalities to enact ordinances for the protection of animals, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-18. DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 6-85. - Applicability to dogs and cats. This article applies to all animals, including dogs and cats. However, with regard to dogs and cats, the provisions of this article are supplemental and in addition to the regulations provided in article IV of this chapter. Sec. 6-86. - Adequate food, water, shelter and humane care required. It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any animal to refuse or fail to provide such animal adequate food and water, adequate shelter and humane care, including without limitation as reasonably necessary to prevent malnutrition, dehydration, or physical suffering taking into account the animal's size, age, physical condition, breed, and species. (Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(J)(2)) Sec. 6-87. - Abandonment prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any animal to willfully abandon such animal on any street, road, highway, or public place, or on private property of another person. (Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(J)(3)) Sec. 6-88. - Accumulation of waste matter and unsanitary conditions prohibited. (a) It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any animal to permit the accumulation of waste matter from such animal to collect and remain on the property of the owner or custodian, or on the property of others, so as to cause or create an unhealthy, unsanitary, dangerous, noxious, or offensive living condition for the animal or condition on the owner's or custodian's property, or the abutting property of others. (b) It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any animal to permit or cause unhealthy, unsanitary, dangerous, noxious, or offensive conditions by virtue of the size or number of animals maintained at a single location or due to the inadequacy of the facilities for such animals, taking into account each such animal's size, age, physical condition, breed, and species. (Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(J)(4), (5)) Sec. 6-89. - Restraint required; running at large prohibited; enforcement. (a) It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of any animal to fail to keep such animal under restraint or to permit such animal to roam or run at large, except as otherwise provided in this article. Any dog, while off the property of the owner or upon any private property without the consent of the owner of the property, shall be under restraint by its owner or custodian. (b) Any person finding an animal at large upon his property may use reasonable means to remove the same to the animal shelter or hold the animal in his own possession, and as soon as possible, notify the city. The property owner shall provide a description to the city of the animal and the name of the owner, if known. The city shall dispatch an authorized officer to impound the animal as soon as possible. (c) If the name of the owner of an animal found at large is known or can be obtained with reasonable dispatch, the city at its discretion may return the animal to the residential address of the owner. If there is no responsible person present, or if the city determines in its discretion to otherwise not return the animal, the city shall impound the animal and leave written notice of whom the owner must contact to reclaim the animal. (d) The city may cite the owner of such animal found at large for a violation of this section, and in addition, if such animal is impounded, the owner shall be liable for fees and costs imposed by this section in reclaiming an impounded animal. (Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(D)(1), (D)(2), (E)(3), (G)) Sec. 6-90. - Domestic fowl or livestock at large; impoundment; disposal. (a) It is unlawful for any owner or person in control of any domestic fowl or livestock to allow that domestic fowl or livestock to run at large within the city. It is unlawful for any cattle, hogs, horses or other domestic fowl or livestock to be at large within the corporate limits of the city. (b) It shall be the duty of the chief of police to impound any and all cattle, cows, calves, horses or other domestic fowl or livestock found at large within the corporate limits of the city, and advertise same by posting a full description of such cattle, hogs, horses or other domestic fowl or livestock and giving the date and place where they shall be sold. (c) After such animal or animals have been advertised for sale five days as indicated above, it shall be the duty of the chief of police to sell such animal or animals, and to deduct from the proceeds of the sale a fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule for impoundment, advertising, daily board and feed. (d) The owner may redeem the animal by paying the chief of police the fees and expenses specified in this section. (Code 1989, § 9-3-2(a)) State Law reference— Livestock running at large, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq.; disposal of impounded livestock, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-7. Sec. 6-91. - Pigs not permitted within city limits. It is unlawful to keep any live swine or pigs within the city limits. (Code 1989, § 9-3-3) Sec. 6-92. - Animal enclosure construction and maintenance requirements. Any housing or enclosure used for the keeping of animals or fowl shall be well drained, free from accumulations of animal excrement and objectionable odors, and otherwise clean and sanitary. (Code 1989, § 9-3-4) Sec. 6-93. - Cruelty prohibited. It is unlawful for any person to inflict, cause or permit cruelty to or upon any animal, including without limitation to negligently, willfully or maliciously strike, beat, physically, or mentally abuse, overwork, overload, maim or disfigure, intentionally chase or run down with a vehicle, bicycle, or motorized or powered implement, or otherwise engage in any act or omission causing, inflicting, or resulting in unnecessary pain, injury, physical or mental suffering, abuse, or death to an animal, in each case taking into account the animal's age, size, physical condition, breed, and species, except that reasonable force may be used in self-defense to destroy a vicious or dangerous animals or to drive away trespassing animals as authorized by state law. Examples of acts prohibited by this section include, but are not limited to: (1) Allowing a collar, rope, chain, or other item to become embedded in or cause injury to an animal's neck or other portion of the body. (2) Allowing a slip type choke, or pinch type collar to be used as a primary collar to tether an animal. (3) Intentionally causing or allowing animals to engage in a fight. (4) Allowing animals to live in unsanitary conditions. (5) Allowing animals to live in regularly over-crowded conditions. (6) Failure or refusal to obtain veterinary medical treatment for an animal when, in the opinion of a veterinarian, a law enforcement official, or any officer authorized to enforce the provisions of this chapter, such treatment is needed. (7) Shooting a domestic animal, either on or off of the owner's property, unless such domestic animal is then in the act of attacking or maliciously chasing a human being, horse, hog, goat, poultry, any other domestic animal or sheep or cattle, and shooting such domestic animal is then the most reasonable action under the particular circumstance, except under the direction of a veterinarian or law enforcement official where the animal is hopelessly suffering. (Code 1989, § 9-3-5; Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(K)(a)) State Law reference— Animal protection, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; performing cruel acts on, harming, maiming or killing dogs, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-1. Sec. 6-94. - Poisoning prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally administer poison to any animal, or knowingly leave any poisonous substance of any kind or ground glass or other harmful substance in any place with the intent to injure any animal. This provision is not applicable to licensed pest control exterminators using poisons as part of an insect pest control program or the use of commercial insecticides, rodenticides, or rodent baits used to control insect and wild rodents, or to licensed veterinarians using veterinary pharmaceuticals in providing bona fide veterinary services. (Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(K)(b)) Sec. 6-95. - Authority to remove animals from vehicles. The animal control department may use any force reasonably necessary to remove any animal locked in a closed vehicle if the owner cannot be immediately located. The operator of the vehicle will be charged with cruelty to animals as defined in this chapter. No injunction or claim for damages may be placed against the animal control department or its officers for this action. Sec. 6-96. - Nuisance animals and animals that disturb the peace prohibited. (a) No person owning any dog or any other animal shall suffer or permit such animal to disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood by barking, making other loud or unusual noises, or by running through or across cultivated gardens, lawns, or fields. (b) No owner or custodian of any animal shall fail to exercise proper care and control of such animal to prevent the same from becoming a public nuisance. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any animal on any property located within the city when the keeping of such animal constitutes a public nuisance or menace to public health, welfare, or safety. (Code 1989, § 9-3-6; Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(D)(3), (H)) Sec. 6-97. - Rabies inoculation. It shall be the duty of the owner or person in custody of any animal kept in the city to have the animal inoculated against rabies at least once each year. The certification along with owner identification must be worn around the animal's neck at all times. The owner of an animal subject to this section must possess a current certification of rabies vaccination for each animal owned as provided for by state law. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, §§ 9-3-8, 9-3-15) State Law reference— Responsibility for control of rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1. Sec. 6-98. - Bird sanctuary; destruction of nuisance birds. The entire area embraced within the corporate limits of the city is designated as a bird sanctuary. It is unlawful to trap, hunt, molest or kill any wild bird or to rob any wild bird's nest; provided, however, if nuisance birds such as starlings are found to be congregating in such numbers in a particular locality so as to constitute a nuisance or a menace to health or property in the opinion of the city council, those birds may be destroyed as humanely as possible, under the supervision of the police department, in such numbers and in such manner as is deemed advisable by the city council. (Code 1989, § 9-3-1) Sec. 6-99. - Hunting, trapping, disturbing or killing of wild game prohibited; exception. It is unlawful to trap, hunt, disturb or kill any other wild game in the city except by order of the chief of police. (Code 1989, § 9-3-1) Sec. 6-100. - Destruction of hopelessly disabled animals. Licensed veterinarians, federal, state, and local law enforcement officials, and those authorized by the city manager to administer and enforce the provisions of this section, in each case while acting within the scope of their authority, are authorized to induce the death of hopelessly disabled animals by an appropriately humane method. (Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(C)(1)) Sec. 6-101. - Destruction of contagious, ill animals. (a) In any situation deemed appropriate by an animal services officer involving a sick, diseased, or infected animal which sickness or disease, in the opinion of a licensed veterinarian, or a state or federal employee acting within the scope of his authority, will likely spread to other animals or humans, an authorized officer may impound and take custody of any such animal, the animal shall be isolated, and the owner or custodian of such animal shall be promptly notified. (b) If the owner or custodian cannot be located, the owner or custodian fails to take immediate steps to remove the animal from impoundment, and take immediate steps to isolate the animal to properly eliminate the likelihood of infecting other animals or humans or otherwise spreading the sickness, disease, or infection, or, if in the opinion of a licensed veterinarian, destroying the animal is the most reasonable course of action to eliminate the health or safety risk of the animal spreading the sickness, disease, or infection, then in any such event, the infected animal shall be humanely destroyed in accordance with state law. (c) The owner of any such animal impounded pursuant to this section shall be liable for reimbursement to the city or county, or both, as appropriate for all expenses related to the impoundment, boarding, treatment, and destruction of any such animal. (Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(C)(2)) Secs. 6-102—6-130. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - VICIOUS AND DANGEROUS ANIMALS
Sec. 6-131. - Duty of animal owners and custodians to ensure compliance. (a) It shall be the duty of every owner or custodian of any vicious animal to ensure that it is kept under restraint and that reasonable care and precautions are taken to prevent it from leaving the real property limits of its owner, possessor, or custodian, and ensure compliance with the provisions of this division. (b) It shall be unlawful for an owner or custodian of a vicious dog to permit the dog within the city to be outside a proper, secure enclosure unless the dog is restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the physical restraint of a responsible person. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-34; Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(C)) Sec. 6-132. - Confinement or restraint required. (a) Compliance required. It is unlawful for any person to cause, permit, accompany or be responsible for the presence of any vicious dog or cat on the streets or public places of the city or allow the animal to run on the premises of another, at any time except in compliance with this section. (b) Enclosure. Every vicious or dangerous animal shall be securely and humanely enclosed within a house, building, fence, pen or other enclosure out of which it cannot climb, dig, jump, or otherwise escape on its own volition. Such enclosure is securely locked at any time the animal is left unattended. (c) Leashing. Whenever the animal is outside of its enclosure as provided for above, but on the owner's property, it must be attended by the owner and restrained by a secure collar and leash of sufficient strength to prevent escape. The leash shall be no longer than ten feet, and the animal must be kept at least 15 feet within the perimeter boundaries of the property unless the perimeter is securely fenced. (d) Tethering. No vicious animal shall be chained, tethered, or otherwise tied to any inanimate object such as a tree, post, or building, outside of an enclosure meeting the specifications of this section. (e) Muzzling. If any persons shall cause, permit, accompany or be responsible for the presence of any vicious dog or cat on the streets or in public places within the city or on the premises of another, the animal shall be securely muzzled to effectively prevent it from biting any person or another animal. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-34(1)—(4)) Sec. 6-133. - Inspection of enclosures. All enclosures or housing units for vicious and dangerous animals will be inspected by the animal control agent. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-34(5)) Sec. 6-134. - Enforcement procedure; penalties; disposition. (a) Impoundment. An animal may be immediately confiscated and held by any law enforcement official, or those authorized by the city to administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter, while acting within the scope of their respective authority, if the animal without provocation has: (1) Killed, bitten, or otherwise severely injured a person or another domestic animal; (2) Repeatedly chased or otherwise threatened persons or other domestic animals in a vicious or menacing manner indicating a reasonable likelihood that the animal will cause imminent physical injury; or (3) Repeatedly caused significant damage to the property of other than that of its owner or custodian. The impounded animal shall be confined in the county animal shelter pending a hearing, if necessary, to determine whether such animal should be destroyed as a public nuisance and, if not, in the case of a dog, classified as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog. (b) Notice to owner. The owner of any animal that has been so confiscated shall be given notice of said animal's confiscation. The notice to the owner shall be in writing and sent by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery to the last known address of the owner. The notice shall give a description of the animal and set forth the reasons that the animal has been confiscated, together with the date, time, and place of the hearing. (c) Time for holding hearing. A hearing before the city shall be scheduled within 15 days from the date of notice to the owner of the animal's confiscation to determine if the animal should be destroyed as a public nuisance. At said hearing, the owner of the confiscated animal shall have the right to present testimony and evidence as to why the animal should not be destroyed as a public nuisance. (d) Factors to be considered at hearing. The city, after receiving all pertinent testimony and evidence on the matter, shall decide whether the animal shall be destroyed as a public nuisance. In making its decision, the city shall consider whether the animal constitutes such a physical threat to persons or other animals, or of significant destruction or harm to property, by virtue of one or more unprovoked attacks on persons, other domestic animals, or physical property that destruction of the animal is reasonably necessary to protect the health, welfare, or property in the city. (e) Determination that animal must be destroyed. If the city decides that said animal should be destroyed, then the owner shall promptly be given written notice thereof, and the animal shall be humanely destroyed any time after five business days after the date of such written notice of the decision of the city in accordance with state law. (f) Determination that animal is a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog. If the city decides the animal should not be destroyed, the city shall determine whether such animal shall be classified as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog. If the city determines that such dog shall be classified as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, the owner shall promptly be given written notice thereof, and the dog shall continue to be impounded by city until the owner shall have complied with all the requirements of this article, after which the animal will be returned to the owner. If the owner fails to meet said requirements within ten business days following written notice of the decision of the authorized official classifying of the dog as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, or to timely request a hearing appealing such decision, the dog shall be humanely destroyed in accordance with state law; provided, however, that the city may extend said time for up to an additional 15-day period upon payment by the owner of the per diem boarding costs for said dog. (g) Fees and costs. The owner of an animal confiscated under the provisions of this section shall pay a fee of $50.00 and reimburse the city for all costs of housing, feeding, and any medical treatment of said animal. (Code 1989, § 9-3-7; Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(C)) Secs. 6-135—6-151. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - DOGS AND CATS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 6-152. - Maximum number of dogs and cats per lot. It shall be unlawful to keep more than two dogs or two cats on any one lot; provided, however, that an exception is made and an additional dog may be kept on a lot when the occupant or owner of the premises has a medical need or is handicapped and the dog in question is a trained animal used to benefit or aid a handicapped or medically ill individual. (Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(J)(1)) Sec. 6-153. - Running at large prohibited. (a) It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any cat to allow the cat to roam free on the property of another without permission of the owner or person in possession of that property, or without such cat wearing a collar with a current rabies tag attached. (b) It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any dog to allow the dog to roam or run free on the property of another without the permission of the owner or person in possession of that property, or without such dog wearing a collar with a current rabies control tag attached. (Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(J)(6), (7)) Sec. 6-154. - Confinement of female dogs and cats in heat required. Every female dog or cat, which is not sterilized, during the period it is in heat shall be confined in a building or other enclosure in such a manner that such female dog or cat cannot come into contact with another animal of the same species or breed, except for planned breeding. (Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(D)(4)) State Law reference— Permitting dogs in heat to run free prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6. Sec. 6-155. - Removal of dog feces from certain areas. The owner, keeper, walker or person in charge of any dog shall not permit solid fecal matter of such animal to deposit on any street, alley, or other public or private property, unless such matter is immediately removed therefrom by said owner or person in charge. This section shall not apply to a person who is visually or physically handicapped. Sec. 6-156. - Running at large prohibited. It is unlawful for the owner or custodian of a dog or cat to allow such animal to run at large in the city. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-12(a)) Sec. 6-157. - Nuisances prohibited; appeal of nuisance classification. It shall be a violation of the article for the owner of any dog or cat to allow the dog or cat to act so as to become a public nuisance dog or cat as defined in this chapter. The owner of any dog or cat which has been classified as a nuisance dog or cat by the animal control unit shall have a right to appeal such classification, in writing, to the city court. The decision of the city court shall be final. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, §§ 9-3-12(b), 9-3-20) Sec. 6-158. - Collar and identification tag required. It shall be a violation of this article for the owner to permit a dog or cat off the premises of that owner's property without a collar and identification tag for each animal. The identification tag shall give the name, current address, and telephone number of the owner. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-12(c)) Secs. 6-159—6-184. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSES
Sec. 6-185. - Required. Any person owning, keeping, harboring, or having custody of any dog or cat over four months of age within this municipality must obtain a license as herein provided. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-35(a)) Sec. 6-186. - Application; fees; rabies vaccination certificate; annual renewal. (a) Application for a license must be made within 30 days after obtaining a dog or cat over four months of age; provided, however, that this requirement will not apply to a nonresident keeping a dog or cat within the municipality for no longer than 60 days. Each license shall be renewed between January 1 and January 31 of the year following issuance and each year thereafter. (b) Written application for licenses, which shall include the name and address of the applicant and a description of the animal, shall be made to the licensing authority, accompanied by a license fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule and a rabies certificate issued by a licensed veterinarian or anti-rabies clinic. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-35(b), (d), (e), (k), (n)) Sec. 6-187. - Term of license; prorated fees. The licensing period shall begin with the fiscal year and shall run for one year. A license application may be made 30 days prior to, and up to 60 days after, the start of the fiscal year. Persons applying for a license during the licensing year shall be required to pay one-half of the fee stipulated in this section. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-35(c), (i)) Sec. 6-188. - Fees; service dogs exempt from fees. Fees for original issuance of licenses and renewal and duplicates thereof shall be in the amounts provided in the city fee schedule. License fees shall not be required for certified service dogs, governmental police dogs, or other certified dogs that are trained to assist the physically handicapped. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-35(e)) Sec. 6-189. - Tag and identification collar to be issued and fastened to collar or harness. Upon acceptance of the license application and fee, the licensing authority shall issue a durable tag or identification collar, stamped with an identifying number and the year of issuance. Tags should be designed so that they may be conveniently fastened or riveted to the animal's collar or harness. Dogs and cats must wear identification tags or collars at all times when off the premises of the owners. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-35(f), (g)) Sec. 6-190. - Record of issued tags to be maintained and made public. The licensing authority shall maintain a record of the identifying numbers of all tags issued and shall make this record available to the public at all times. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-35(h)) Sec. 6-191. - License to be used only for animal for which issued. No person may use any license for any animal other than the animal for which it was issued. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-35(m)) Sec. 6-192. - Duplicate licenses. A duplicate license may be obtained upon payment of a replacement fee in the amount specified in the city fee schedule. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-35(l)) Secs. 6-193—6-222. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - DANGEROUS AND POTENTIALLY DANGEROUS DOGS FOOTNOTE(S): --- (4) --- State Law reference— Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.; vicious dog control (Mercedes' Law), O.C.G.A. § 4-8-40 et seq.; duties of cities with regard to dangerous dogs, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-22; registration of dangerous dogs, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-25; muzzling and restraint, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-26; confiscation and destruction, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-27. DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 6-223. - Registration. (a) Required; issuance. It is unlawful for an owner to have or possess within the city limits a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog without a certificate of registration issued in accordance with the provisions of this division. The animal enforcement agent or police officer shall issue a certificate of registration to the owner of such dog if the owner presents to the animal enforcement agent sufficient evidence of compliance with the provisions of this division and pays the registration fee in the amount specified in the city fee schedule. (b) Time for registration of dogs owned by new residents. The owner of a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog who is a new resident of the city shall register the dog as required in this section within 30 days after becoming a resident. (c) Annual renewal. Certificate of registration shall be renewed on an annual basis. At the time of the renewal of a certificate of registration, an animal enforcement agent or police officer shall require evidence from the owner or make such investigations as may be necessary to verify that all requirements of this division continue to be met. Application for renewal shall be accompanied by a renewal fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. (d) Certificate not a guarantee. Issuance of a certificate of registration or the renewal of a certificate of registration by the city does not warrant or guarantee that the requirements specified in subsections (b) and (c) of this section were met or are maintained by the owner of a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-29(a), (b), (f), (h); Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(I)(3)) Sec. 6-224. - Warning signs. The owner or custodian of a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog shall post a clearly visible sign on the premises where the dog is located warning that there is a dangerous dog on the property. Such sign shall prominently display the dangerous dog symbol designed by the state department of natural resources pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 4-8-25(b)(2)(B). (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-29(b)) Sec. 6-225. - Insurance or bond. The owner or custodian of a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog shall acquire and maintain at all times in full force and effect a policy of insurance in the amount of at least $15,000.00 issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in this state insuring the owner of the dangerous dog against liability for any personal injuries inflicted by the dangerous dog. Alternatively, the owner or custodian shall acquire and maintain a security bond in the amount of $15,000.00 or more issued by a surety company authorized to transact business in this state payable to any person or persons injured by the dangerous dog. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-29(c)) Sec. 6-226. - Notice of change in status of dog. The owner of a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the city animal control office immediately if the dog is on the loose, is unconfined, has attacked a human, has died or has been sold, donated, or disposed of. If the dog has been sold, donated, or disposed of, the former owner shall provide the animal control office with the name, address, and telephone number of the new owner of the dog. The owner of the dangerous or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the city animal control office if the owner is moving from the incorporated portion of the city. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-29(d), (e)) Sec. 6-227. - Muzzle and leash required for dog outside enclosure. It is unlawful for an owner of a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is muzzled and restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the physical restraint of a responsible person. The muzzle shall be made in a manner that will not cause injury to the dog or interfere with its vision or respiration but will prevent it from biting any person. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-30) Secs. 6-228—6-247. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - CLASSIFICATION PROCEDURE
Sec. 6-248. - Investigation required. Upon receiving a report of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within an animal enforcement agent's jurisdiction from a law enforcement agency, animal control agency, rabies control officer, or county board of health, the animal enforcement agent shall make such investigations and inquiries with regard to such report as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this article. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-27; Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(I)(1)) Sec. 6-249. - Effect of deviations from procedure. As applied to the owners of potentially dangerous dogs, the procedures provided in this division must be carried out as a necessary condition for the enforcement of the provisions of this division against such owners. As applied to the owners of dangerous dogs, the procedures provided in this division shall not be an essential element of any crime provided for in this article. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-28(a); Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(I)(2)) Sec. 6-250. - Notice of classification or reclassification. When a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog is classified as such, and when an animal previously classified as a potentially dangerous dog is reclassified as a dangerous dog, the animal enforcement agent or police officer shall notify the dog's owner of such classification or reclassification. The notice to the owner shall be in writing and mailed by certified mail to the owner's last known address. The notice shall: (1) Include a summary of the enforcing officer's findings that formed the basis for the dog's classification as a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog; (2) Be dated and state that the owner, within 15 days after the date shown on the notice, has a right to request a hearing on the enforcing officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog; (3) State that the hearing, if requested, shall be before the city court and, if a hearing is not requested, the enforcing officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog will become effective for all purposes under this article on a date specified in the notice, which shall be after the last day on which the owner has a right to request a hearing; and (4) Include a form to request a hearing before the applicable court and shall provide specific instructions on mailing or delivering such request to the court. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-28(b), (c); Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(I)(2)(b)) Sec. 6-251. - Requests for hearing; effect of failure to appear; costs. (a) The city shall conduct hearings when requested under this section by the owner aggrieved by a decision of an authorized officer with respect to classifying such owner's dog as a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog, or the reclassification of a potentially dangerous dog as a dangerous dog. (b) Request for hearing shall be made by the animal owner within five business days of receiving a notice of a right to request such hearing. Any person who requests a hearing, provided for in this section but who, after receipt of notice of the hearing, fails to appear at said hearing shall be deemed to have abandoned the hearing request and the decision of the authorized officer which was to be the subject of such hearing shall be affirmed and final. (c) The owner of an animal requesting a hearing shall pay the additional daily boarding and other fees as established in this article. Failure to pay the fees and costs assessed against the owner, if affirmed by the city, shall constitute an abandonment of any claim to the animal and will result in the animal being disposed of as otherwise provided in this article. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-28(d); Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(I)(2)(c), (M)(1)) Sec. 6-252. - Conduct of hearing. At the hearing, the owner of the dog shall be given the opportunity to testify and present evidence and, in addition thereto, the court shall receive such other evidence and hear such other testimony as the court may find reasonably necessary to make a determination either to sustain, modify, or overrule the enforcing officer's classification of the dog. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-28(d); Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(I)(2)(c)) Sec. 6-253. - Notice of determination. Within ten days after the date of the hearing, the court shall notify the dog owner in writing by certified mail of its determination on the matter. If such determination is that the dog is a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog, the notice shall specify the date upon which the determination is effective, provided that the effective date shall be not less than ten days after the date of this order. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-28(e); Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(I)(2)(d)) Secs. 6-254—6-284. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 6-285. - Investigation authorized. The animal enforcement agent or police officer is authorized to make whatever inquiry is deemed necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this article. Law enforcement agencies of the city shall cooperate with the animal enforcement agent in enforcing the provisions of this article. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-29(g)) Sec. 6-286. - Grounds for confiscation of dog. (a) Dangerous dogs. A dangerous dog shall be immediately confiscated by the animal enforcement agent or police officer or by any law enforcement officer or by any other person authorized by the animal enforcement agent or chief of police if the owner or custodian of the dog does not secure and maintain the required liability insurance or bond, the dog is not registered as required in this article, or the dog is not maintained in a proper enclosure or properly restrained outside a proper enclosure. (b) Potentially dangerous dogs. A potentially dangerous dog shall be confiscated in the same manner as a dangerous dog if the dog is not registered as required in this article or the dog is not maintained in a proper enclosure or properly restrained outside a proper enclosure. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-31(b), (c)) Sec. 6-287. - Redemption. (a) Any dog that has been confiscated under this article shall be returned to its owner upon the owner's compliance with the provisions of this article and upon the payment of reasonable confiscation costs including a daily boarding fee, a pickup fee, and a rabies vaccination fee if the animal's owner does not produce proof of a current rabies vaccination. The amount of all fees shall be as set forth in the city fee schedule. (b) In the event the owner or custodian of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog has not complied with the provisions of this article within 20 days of the date the dog's classification as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, as the case may be, becomes final or, in the case of a dog previously so classified, 20 days of the date the dog was confiscated, the dog shall be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner in accordance with state law; provided, however, upon a showing of good cause, the city may extend said time, for up to an additional 15-day period, upon the payment by the owner of the per diem boarding costs for said dog. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-31(c); Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(I)(4)(a)) Sec. 6-288. - Penalties for violation. (a) Fine and imprisonment. In addition to any other penalties imposed by state law, the owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who violates the provisions of this article or whose dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is subject to confiscation under this article shall be subject to penalties as provided in section 1-14. (b) Confiscation, quarantine and destruction of dog. In addition, the dangerous dog involved shall be immediately confiscated by the animal enforcement agent or police officer or another person authorized by the animal enforcement agent or chief of police and placed in quarantine for the proper length of time as determined by the county board of health, and, thereafter, the dangerous dog shall be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, §§ 9-3-31, 9-3-32; Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-4(I)(4)(b)) Sec. 6-289. - Liability for damages. Under no circumstance shall the city or any employee or official thereof who enforces or fails to enforce the provisions of this article be held liable for any damages to any person who suffers an injury inflicted by a dog: (1) That has been identified as being a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog; (2) That has been reported to the proper authorities as being a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; (3) That city officials and employees have failed to identify as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; (4) That has been identified as being a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog but has not been kept or restrained in the manner described in this article; or (5) Whose owner has not maintained insurance coverage or a surety bond as required in this article. (Ord. of 3-11-2002, § 9-3-33)

div.head: Chapter 8 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS
div.p:
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Municipal home rule, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II; O.C.G.A. § 36-35-1 et seq.; standards and requirements for construction, alteration, etc., of buildings and other structures, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq.; building trade contractors, O.C.G.A. § 43-14-1 et seq.; enforcement of adopted codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26; state minimum standards codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-21; county building, electrical, and other codes, O.C.G.A. § 36-13-1 et seq.; local government code enforcement boards, O.C.G.A. § 36-74-1 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 8-1. - Scope and effect of provisions. This chapter shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibility of any party owning, operating, repairing, controlling or installing any building, structure or alteration falling within the scope of this chapter from damages to anyone injured thereby, nor shall the city be held as assuming any liability by reason of inspection authorized or certificate issued under this chapter. (Code 1989, § 6-2-9) Sec. 8-2. - Building inspector appointed to enforce chapter. The city has created and established the office of building inspector. The building inspector is appointed by the mayor and city council and serves at their pleasure. The building inspector is charged with the duty of enforcement of this chapter and shall perform other duties as may be prescribed by the mayor and city council. The building inspector appointed by the city council may be a city employee or a county employee. (Code 1989, § 6-2-2) Secs. 8-3—8-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - BUILDING PERMITS
Sec. 8-23. - Required; application; fees. (a) It is unlawful for any person to set up any mobile home within the city or to erect, construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, remove, convert, or destroy any building or structure within the city if the cost of construction will exceed $1,000.00 without first having obtained a building permit. Application for a building permit shall be made to the building inspector on forms prescribed by the city council and shall be accompanied by a fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule and such additional information and supporting documentation as the building inspector may require. (b) The issuance or granting of a permit or approval of plans or specifications shall not be deemed or construed to be a permit for, or an approval of, any violation of any of the provisions of chapter 40, pertaining to zoning, or of any other chapter of the city. No permit presuming to give the authority to violate or cancel the provisions of chapter 40, pertaining to zoning, shall be valid, except insofar as the work or use which it authorizes is lawful. (c) Issuance of a permit upon plans and specifications shall not prevent the building inspector or city from thereafter requiring the correction of errors in such plans and specifications, or from thereafter preventing building operations being carried on thereunder when in violation of chapter 40, pertaining to zoning, or of any other chapter of the city. Permits for construction and uses which require a conditional use or variance to the general requirements of chapter 40, pertaining to zoning, shall be issued by the building inspector only upon order of the city council. (Code 1989, §§ 6-2-1, 6-2-3; Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 9.02) Sec. 8-24. - Application requirements. No permit shall be issued for the construction, alteration, remodeling, or placement of any building, sign, structure, or manufactured home, until a written application is filed with the city by the owner of the property affected or by the authorized agent of such owner. The application shall at a minimum: (1) Include all forms as may be provided by the zoning administrator or other city representative for such purpose, and must include all required information on the forms by the applicant. (2) Include a surveyors plat of the property affected. (3) Include a detailed statement as to the proposed use of the building or land for which a permit is sought. (4) Include plans in duplicate drawn to scale showing the actual dimensions and shape of the lot to be built upon; the exact sizes and locations on the lot of buildings already existing, if any; the location and dimensions of the proposed building, sign, manufactured home, or alteration. (5) If the development for which the permit is other than a single-family or small agricultural use, a more formal site plan may be required by the zoning administrator. This site plan shall be provided in triplicate and submitted with the application and shall show the following at a scale not more than 50 feet to the inch: a. Title, if any, under which the proposed development is to be recorded and the name of the present owner. b. Names of owners of adjacent property. c. A topographic map showing the location of existing property lines, streets, alleys, buildings, easements, watercourses, and other physical site features, including the location of existing trees of four inches or larger in caliper as measured at breast height. d. The exact size, shape, and location of the building or structure to be erected thereon with exact distances from the building or structure to property lines and street rights-of-way. e. Other proposed improvements, landscaping, or buffers proportionally and exactly dimensioned. f. Proposed method of water supply, sewage disposal, and storm drainage. g. All proposed uses of the property to be developed appropriately indicated on the plan. h. Other information as may be required to insure compliance with the provisions of this chapter. i. Date, north arrow, and graphic scale. j. The name and address of a registered surveyor or engineer chosen by the applicant who is authorized to stake the road lines and location of such proposed development. (6) Other such information as may be required by the zoning administrator to determine compliance with and provide for enforcement of this chapter. (7) In addition, the zoning administrator may require certified "as-built" site plans or other information necessary to determine chapter and initial permit compliance before issuing a certificate of occupancy. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 9.03) Sec. 8-25. - Denial of application for permit. If the application for a building permit is not approved, the building inspector shall immediately notify the applicant in writing on the application the cause for denial. Upon receipt of notice, the applicant may re-apply for a building permit, provided he overcomes, to the satisfaction of the building inspector, the causes for the previous denial, or he may institute appeal proceedings. (Code 1989, § 6-2-4) Sec. 8-26. - Building permit valuations. If, in the opinion of the building inspector, the valuation of the building, alteration, or structure appears to be underestimated on the application, the application for building permit shall be denied, unless the applicant can show detailed estimated costs to meet the approval of the building inspector. Permit valuations shall include total costs, such as plumbing, electrical, mechanical equipment and other systems. (Code 1989, § 6-2-5) Sec. 8-27. - Penalties. Any person failing to obtain a building permit before commencing construction shall be punished by fine of not more than $100.00 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 30 days or both of these punishments. (Code 1989, § 6-2-6) Secs. 8-28—8-51. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - BUILDING AND TECHNICAL CODES
Sec. 8-52. - Adopted by reference; copies to be made publicly available. (a) The city adopts, to the extent applicable in the city, as though fully set forth herein, the following state minimum standards codes and permissive codes, as set forth in O.C.G.A. §§ 8-2-20 and 8-2-21, as supplemented and amended by the state department of community affairs, and as may be amended by provisions of this chapter or of this Code generally: (1) International Building Code, 2006 Edition; (2) International Residential Code, 2006 Edition; (3) International Fire Code, 2006 Edition; (4) International Plumbing Code, 2006 Edition; (5) International Mechanical Code, 2006 Edition; (6) International Fuel Gas Code, 2009 Edition; (7) National Electrical Code, 2011 Edition; (8) International Energy Conservation Code, 2009 Edition; (9) International Property Maintenance Code, 2006 Edition; and (10) International Existing Building Code, 2006 Edition. (b) Subsequent editions or amendments to the adopted publications and state amendments and errata shall become effective 30 days after the city council receives notice that copies of such publications have been obtained, unless the council within such 30-day period disapproves the subsequent edition or amendment. (c) A copy of each adopted code of technical regulations, as well as the adopting ordinance, shall be authenticated and recorded by the clerk and kept on file in the office of the clerk where they shall be available for public inspection. Sec. 8-53. - Codes remedial in nature. The city's technical codes are remedial in nature, and shall be construed to secure the beneficial interests and purposes thereof, which are public safety, health, and general welfare through structural strength, stability, sanitation, adequate light and ventilation, and safety to life and property from fire and other hazards attributed to the built environment including alteration, repair, removal, demolition, use and occupancy of buildings, structures, or premises, and by regulating the installation and maintenance of all electrical, gas, mechanical and plumbing systems (herein "service systems"). Sec. 8-54. - Quality control. Quality control of materials and workmanship is not within the purview of this Code except as it relates to the purposes stated herein. Sec. 8-55. - Liability of city. The inspection or permitting of any building, system or plan under the requirements of this Code shall not be construed in any court as a warranty of the physical condition of such building, system or plan or their adequacy. Neither the city nor any employee thereof shall be liable in tort for damages for any defect or hazardous or illegal condition or inadequacy in such building, system or plan, nor for any failure of any component of such, that may occur subsequent to such inspection or permitting. Sec. 8-56. - Conflict of regulations. Where in any specific case sections of the technical codes, of this Code, and of state or federal laws or regulations specify different materials, methods of construction or other requirements, the most restrictive shall govern. Where there is a conflict between a general requirement and a specific requirement, the specific requirement shall be applicable. Sec. 8-57. - Appendices to technical codes. Appendices referenced in the code text of the technical codes shall be considered an integral part of the codes. Sec. 8-58. - Referenced standards. Standards referenced in the text of the technical codes shall be considered an integral part of the codes. If specific portions of a standard are denoted by code text, only those portions of the standard shall be enforced. Where code provisions conflict with a standard, the code provisions shall be enforced. Permissive and advisory provisions in a standard shall not be construed as mandatory. Sec. 8-59. - Requirements not covered by code. Any requirements necessary for the strength, stability or proper operation of an existing or proposed building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system, or for the public safety, health and general welfare, not specifically covered by this or the other technical codes, shall be determined by the building inspector. Sec. 8-60. - Alternate materials and methods. The provisions of the technical codes are not intended to prevent the use of any material or method of construction not specifically prescribed by them, provided any such alternate has been reviewed by the building inspector. The building inspector shall approve any such alternate, provided the building inspector finds that the alternate for the purpose intended is at least the equivalent of that prescribed in the technical codes, in quality, strength, effectiveness, fire resistance, durability and safety. The building inspector shall require that sufficient evidence or proof be submitted to substantiate any claim made regarding the alternate. Sec. 8-61. - Existing buildings to comply. Alterations, repairs or rehabilitation work may be made to any existing structure, building, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system without requiring the building, structure, plumbing, electrical, mechanical or gas system to comply with all the requirements of the technical codes, provided that the alteration, repair or rehabilitation work conforms to the requirements of the technical codes for new construction. The building inspector shall determine the extent to which the existing system shall be made to conform to the requirements of the technical codes for new construction. Sec. 8-62. - Change of occupancy. If the occupancy classification of any existing building or structure is changed, the building, electrical, gas, mechanical and plumbing systems shall be made to conform to the intent of the technical codes as required by the building inspector. Secs. 8-63—8-88. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - UNFIT STRUCTURES
Sec. 8-89. - Enforcement officer designated. The building inspector is designated as the public officer authorized to exercise the powers prescribed by this article, including the power and duty to: (1) Investigate the structure and dwelling conditions in the city to determine their fitness for human habitation or current commercial or business use; (2) Administer oaths and affirmations, to examine witnesses and receive evidence; (3) Enter upon premises for the purpose of making such examinations, provided it is in such manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the person in possession; (4) Appoint and fix duties of such officers and agents as deemed necessary to carry out the purpose of this article; and (5) Delegate powers and functions under this article to such officers and agents as he may designate. (Code 1989, § 6-5-1) Sec. 8-90. - Procedure for filing charges and serving notice. A public officer or five residents of the city may file a request with the building inspector, or the building inspector may make such a motion on his own, charging that a structure is unfit. The building inspector will make a preliminary investigation to determine if there is a basis for the charges. If he finds there is a basis, he will issue and cause to be served a complaint upon the owner of and any parties in interest in such structure. The complaint will state the charges and contain a notice that a hearing will be held before the building inspector or his designated agent at a place within the city not less than ten days nor more than 30 days after the serving of the complaint. (Code 1989, § 6-5-2) Sec. 8-91. - Right to file an answer. The owner and any parties in interest have the right to file an answer to the complaint and appear in person, or otherwise, and give testimony at the hearing. The rules of evidence prevailing in courts of law or equity shall not be controlling in the hearings before the building inspector. (Code 1989, § 6-5-3) Sec. 8-92. - Findings. (a) After notice and hearing, the building inspector may determine that a dwelling is unfit for human habitation of its current commercial or business use if he finds conditions in the structure that are dangerous or injurious to the health, safety or welfare of the occupants of the dwelling or of neighboring dwellings or of other residents in the municipality. Such conditions may include but are not limited to, dilapidation, disrepair, structural defects, uncleanliness, lack of adequate ventilation, lack of adequate light, lack of adequate sanitary facilities, and defects increasing the hazards of fire, accidents, or other calamities. The building inspector shall state in writing his findings of fact in support of his determination. (b) If the building inspector finds the structure is not unfit, the matter will be closed. If the building inspector finds the structure is unfit, his findings of fact must include a determination of whether the cost of repair would exceed one-half the value such structure will have when repaired to satisfy the minimum requirements of law. (Code 1989, § 6-5-4) Sec. 8-93. - Issuance of orders. The building inspector shall issue and cause to be served upon each person in possession of the property, each owner, and each party in interest an order: (1) If the repair, alteration or improvement of the structure can be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the value of the structure, requiring the owner or parties in interest within a time specified in the order to repair, alter, or improve the structure so as to render it fit for human habitation or its current commercial use or to vacate and close the dwelling as a human habitation; or (2) If the repair, alteration or improvement cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the value of the structure, requiring the owner to remove or demolish the structure. In no event shall the building inspector order removal or demolition except upon a finding that the cost of repair exceeds one-half the value such structure will have when repaired to satisfy the minimum requirements of law. (Code 1989, § 6-5-5) Sec. 8-94. - Proof of service of complaints and orders. (a) Complaints or orders issued by the building inspector shall in all cases be served upon each person in possession, each owner and party in interest. The return of service signed by the building inspector or his agent or an affidavit of service executed by any state citizen shall be sufficient evidence of service. (b) Service upon parties who reside outside the municipality shall be by the sheriff or any other duly authorized law enforcement or other officer of the county of the residence of such party or by any duly authorized citizen. The return of such sheriff or deputy of the affidavit of such citizen stating that the parties were served either personally or by leaving a copy of the complaint or orders at their residence shall be conclusive as to service. (c) Nonresidents of this state shall be served by publishing the notice once each week for two successive weeks in the local newspaper. A copy of the complaint or orders shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises affected. If the address of the nonresidents is known, a copy of such complaint or orders shall be mailed to them by registered or certified mail. (d) If the whereabouts of any owner or party in interest is unknown and cannot be ascertained in the exercise of reasonable diligence, the building inspector shall make an affidavit to that effect and service shall be made by publication as provided in this section for nonresidents. In the alternative, service may be made upon any person, firm or corporation holding itself out as an agent for the property involved. (e) A copy of such complaint or orders shall also be filed in the proper office or offices for the filing of lis pendens notice in the county in which the structure is located. Any such complaint or orders or an appropriate lis pendens notice may contain a statement to the effect that a lien may arise against the described property and that an itemized statement of such lien is maintained on a lien docket maintained by the city clerk. (Code 1989, § 6-5-6) Sec. 8-95. - Failure to comply with order. (a) If the owner or parties in interest fail to comply with an order to vacate and close or demolish the structure, the building inspector may cause such structure to be repaired, altered or improved or to be vacated and closed or demolished. He may cause to be posted on the main entrance of the structure so closed a placard with the following words: "This building is unfit for human habitation or commercial, industrial, or business use; the use or occupation of this building for human habitation or for commercial, industrial, or business use is prohibited and unlawful." (b) Before the building inspector may exercise the duties outlined in this section, an ordinance must be passed by the mayor and council finding that the specific structure is unfit and ordering the building inspector to proceed to effectuate the purpose of this article. (Code 1989, § 6-5-7) Sec. 8-96. - Cost of vacating and closing or removal and demolition. (a) The cost of vacating and closing or removal or demolition by the city shall be a lien against the real property upon which such costs were incurred. The lien shall attach upon the payment of all costs of demolition and the filing of an itemized statement of the total sum of the costs by the building inspector in the office of the city clerk on a lien docket maintained by the clerk for such purposes. (b) If the structure is removed or demolished by the building inspector, he shall sell the material from the structure and credit the proceeds of the sale against the cost of the removal or demolition. Any balance remaining shall be deposited in the superior court by the building inspector, shall be secured in such manner as may be directed by the court and shall be disbursed by the court to persons found to be entitled thereto by final order or decree of the court. (Code 1989, § 6-5-8) Sec. 8-97. - Collection of amount due on a lien. The city may enforce the collection of any amount due on such a lien for demolition or removal of a structure in the following manner: (1) The owner or parties at interest shall be allowed to satisfy the amount due by paying to the city within 30 days after the perfection of the lien, a sum of money equal to 25 percent of the total due. The remaining balance together with an interest rate of seven percent per annum shall be paid to the city in three equal annual payments, each of which will come due and payable on the anniversary date of the initial payment. (2) Should the property upon which the lien is perfected be sold, transferred, or conveyed by the owner or parties at interest at any time prior to the termination of the three-year period, then the entire balance shall be due and payable to the city. (3) Should the amount due on such lien, or any portion thereof, be unpaid after the passage of the three-year period or upon the occurrence of the contingency provided for in subsection (2) of this section, the city may enforce collection of any amount due on such lien for alteration, repair, removal, or demolition of such structure. Collection will be made pursuant to state law. (Code 1989, § 6-5-9) Sec. 8-98. - Other unsafe conditions. All the provisions of this article, including method and procedure, may also be applied to private property where an accumulation of weeds, trash, junk, filth and other unsanitary or unsafe conditions shall create a public health hazard or a general nuisance to those persons residing in the vicinity. A finding of any governmental health department, health official or building inspector that such property is a health hazard shall constitute prima facie evidence that the property is in violation of this article. (Code 1989, § 6-5-10) Secs. 8-99—8-124. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - BUILDING NUMBERING
Sec. 8-125. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to establish that all lots, houses, buildings, offices, and structures within the corporate limits of the city shall be properly and orderly numbered in accordance with the master plan of proper and orderly numbering as established by the mayor and council. (Code 1989, § 6-10-1) Sec. 8-126. - Proper numbering chart. The city shall keep a chart showing proper street numbers and shall assign to every building or lot the proper number by which it is to be designated. (Code 1989, § 6-10-2) Sec. 8-127. - Numbers on houses. It shall be the duty of the owners and occupants of every house or building within the city limits to have placed thereon, in a place visible from the street, figures at least 2½ inches high, showing the proper number of such house or building. (Code 1989, § 6-10-3)

div.head: Chapter 16 - ENVIRONMENT
div.p:
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Conservation and natural resources, O.C.G.A. § 12-1-1 et seq.; water resources, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-1 et seq.; control of soil erosion and sedimentation, O.C.G.A. § 12-7-1 et seq.; control of water pollution and surface water use, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-20; Metropolitan River Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-4-440 et seq.; Georgia Water Quality Control Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-20 et seq.; Georgia Surface Mining Act of 1968, O.C.G.A. § 12-4-70 et seq.; Erosion and Sedimentation Act of 1975, O.C.G.A. § 12-7-1 et seq. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 16-1—16-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - SOIL EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION
Sec. 16-19. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Best Management Practices (BMPs) means a collection of structural measures and vegetative practices which, when properly designed, installed and maintained, will provide effective erosion and sedimentation control for all rainfall events up to and including a 25-year, 24-hour rainfall event. Board means the state board of natural resources. Buffer means an area along the course of any state waters to be maintained in an undisturbed and natural condition. Commission means the state soil and water conservation commission. Cut and excavation means a portion of land surface or area from which earth has been removed or will be removed by excavation; the depth below original ground surface to excavated surface. Also known as "excavation." Department means the state department of natural resources. Director means the director of the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources. District means the Ogeechee Soil and Water Conservation District. Division means the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources. Drainage structure means a device composed of a virtually nonerodible material such as concrete, steel, plastic or other such material that conveys water from one place to another by intercepting the flow and carrying it to a release point from stormwater management, drainage control, or flood control purposes. Erosion means the process by which land surface is worn away by the action of wind, water, ice or gravity. Erosion and sedimentation control plan means a plan for the control of soil erosion and sedimentation resulting from a land disturbing activity. (Also known as the "plan.") Fill means a portion of land surface to which soil or other solid material has been added; the depth above the original ground. Finished grade means the final elevation and contour of the ground after cutting or filling and conforming to the proposed design. Ground elevation means the original elevation of the ground surface prior to cutting or filling. Grading means altering the shape of ground surfaces to a predetermined condition; this includes stripping, cutting, filling, stockpiling and shaping or any combination thereof and shall include the land in its cut or filled condition. Issuing authority means the governing authority of any county or municipality which has been certified by the director of the environmental protection division of the department of natural resources as an issuing authority, pursuant to the Erosion and Sedimentation Act of 1975, as amended, or the division in those instances where an application for a permit is submitted to the division. Land disturbing activity means any activity which may result in soil erosion from water or wind and the movement of sediments into state water or onto lands within the state, including, but not limited to, clearing, dredging, grading, excavating, transporting, and filling of land, but not including agricultural practices as described in section 16-20(5). Metropolitan River Protection Act (MRPA) means a state law referenced as O.C.G.A. § 12-5-440 et seq., which addresses environmental and developmental matters in certain metropolitan river corridors and their drainage basins. Natural ground surface means the ground surface in its original state before any grading, excavation or filling. Nephelometric Turbidity Units (NTU) means numerical units of measure based upon photometric analytical techniques for measuring the light scattered by finely divided particles of a substance in suspension. This technique is used to estimate the extent of turbidity in water in which colloidally dispersed particles are present. Permit means the authorization necessary to conduct a land disturbing activity under the provisions of this chapter. Person means any individual, partnership, firm, association, joint venture, public or private corporation, trust, estate, commission, board, public or private institution, utility, cooperative, state agency, municipality or other political subdivision of this state, any interstate body or any other legal entity. Project means the entire proposed development project, regardless of the size of the area of land to be disturbed. Roadway drainage structure means a device such as a bridge, culvert, or ditch, composed of a virtually nonerodible material such as concrete, steel, plastic, or other such material that conveys water under a roadway by intercepting the flow on one side of a traveled way consisting of one or more defined lanes, with or without shoulder areas, and carrying water to a release point on the other side. Sediment means solid material, both organic and inorganic, that is in suspension, is being transported, or has been moved from its site of origin by air, water, ice or gravity as a product of erosion. Sedimentation means the process by which eroded material is transported and deposited by the action of water, wind, ice or gravity. Soil and water conservation district approved plan means an erosion and sedimentation control plan approved in writing by the Ogeechee Soil and Water Conservation District. Stabilization means the process of establishing an enduring soil cover of vegetation by the installation of temporary or permanent structures for the purpose of reducing to a minimum the erosion process and the resultant transport of sediment by wind, water, ice or gravity. State waters means any and all rivers, streams, creeks, branches, lakes, reservoirs, ponds, drainage systems, springs, wells, and other bodies of surface or subsurface water, natural or artificial, lying within or forming a part of the boundaries of the state which are not entirely confined and retained completely upon the property of a single individual, partnership, or corporation. Structural erosion and sedimentation control measures means measures for the stabilization of erodible or sediment-producing areas by utilizing the mechanical properties of matter for the purpose of either changing the surface of the land, or storing, regulating or disposing of runoff to prevent excessive sediment loss. Examples of structural erosion and sediment control practices are riprap, sediment basins, dikes, level spreaders, waterways or outlets, diversions, grade stabilization structures, sediment traps and land grading, etc. Such measures can be found in the publication "Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia." Trout streams means all streams or portions of streams within the watershed as designated by the game and fish division of the state department of natural resources under the provisions of the Georgia Water Quality Control Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-20 et seq. Streams designated as primary trout waters are defined as water supporting a self-sustaining population of rainbow, brown or brook trout. Streams designated as secondary trout waters are those in which there is no evidence of natural trout reproduction, but are capable of supporting trout throughout the year. First order trout waters are streams into which no other streams flow except springs. Vegetative erosion and sedimentation control practices means practices for the stabilization of erodible or sediment-producing areas by covering the soil with: (1) Permanent seeding, sprigging or planting, producing long-term vegetative cover; (2) Temporary seeding, producing short-term vegetative cover; or (3) Sodding, covering areas with a turf of perennial sod-forming grass. Such practices can be found in the publication, "Manual for Erosion and Sediment Control in Georgia." Watercourse means any natural or artificial watercourse, stream, river, creek, channel, ditch, canal, conduit, culvert, drain, waterway, gully, ravine, or wash in which water flows either continuously or intermittently and which has a definite channel, bed and banks, and including any area adjacent thereto subject to inundation by reason of overflow or floodwater. Wetlands means those areas that are inundated or saturated by surface water or groundwater at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and that under normal circumstances do support a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions. Wetlands generally include swamps, marches, bogs, and similar areas. (Ord. of 8-12-1996, § II) Sec. 16-20. - Exemptions. This article shall apply to any land disturbing activity undertaken by any person on any land except for the following: (1) Surface mining, as the same is defined in O.C.G.A. § 12-4-72; (2) Granite quarrying and land clearing for such quarrying; (3) Such minor land disturbing activities as home gardens and individual home landscaping, repairs, maintenance work, fences, and other related activities which result in minor soil erosion; (4) The construction of single-family residences, when such are constructed by or under contract with the owner for his own occupancy or the construction of single-family residences not a part of a platted subdivision, a planned community, or an association of other residential lots consisting of more than two lots and not otherwise exempted under this subsection; provided, however, that construction of any such residence shall conform to the minimum requirements as set forth in article III of this chapter. For single-family residence construction covered by the provisions of this subsection, there shall be a buffer zone between the residence and any state waters classified as trout streams pursuant to the Georgia Water Quality Control Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-20 et seq. In any such buffer zone, no land disturbing activity shall be constructed between the residence and the point where vegetation has been wrested by normal stream flow or wave action from the banks of the trout waters. For primary trout waters, the buffer zone shall be at least 50 horizontal feet, and no variance to a smaller buffer shall be granted. For secondary trout waters, the buffer zone shall be at least 50 horizontal feet, but the director may grant variances to no less than 25 feet. Regardless of whether a trout stream is primary or secondary, for first order trout waters, which are streams into which no other streams flow except for springs, the buffer shall be at least 25 horizontal feet, and no variance to a smaller buffer shall be granted. The minimum requirements of article III of this chapter and the buffer zones provided by this section shall be enforced by the issuing authority; (5) Agricultural operations as defined in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3 to include raising, harvesting or storing products of the field or orchard; feeding, breeding or managing livestock or poultry; producing or storing feed for use in the production of livestock, including but not limited to cattle, calves, swine, hogs, goats, sheep, and rabbits or for use in the production of poultry, including but not limited to chickens, hens and turkeys; producing plants, trees, fowl, or animals; the production of aquaculture, horticultural, dairy, livestock, poultry, eggs and apiarian products; and forestry land management practices, including harvesting and farm buildings and farm ponds; (6) Any project carried out under the technical supervision of the Natural Resources Conservation Service of the United States Department of Agriculture; (7) Any project involving 11/10 acres or less; provided, however, that this exemption shall not apply to any land disturbing activity within 200 feet of the bank of any state waters and for purposes of this subsection, the term "state waters" excludes channels and drainageways which have water in them only during and immediately after rainfall events and intermittent streams which do not have water in them yearround; provided, however, that any person responsible for a project which involves 1/10 acre or less, which involves land disturbing activity, and which is within 200 feet of any such excluded channel or drainageway, must prevent sediment from moving beyond the boundaries of the property on which such project is located and provided further, that nothing contained herein shall prevent the issuing authority from regulating any such project which is not specifically exempted by subsection 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, or 9 of this section; (8) Construction or maintenance projects, or both, undertaken or financed in whole or in part, or both, by the department of transportation, the state highway authority, or the state tollway authority; or any road construction or maintenance project, or both, undertaken by any county or municipality; provided, however, that such projects shall conform to the minimum requirements set forth in article III of this chapter; (9) Any land disturbing activities conducted by any electric membership corporation or municipal electrical system or any public utility under the regulatory jurisdiction of the public service commission, provided that any such land disturbing activity shall conform to the minimum requirements set forth in sections 16-45 and 16-46. Where this section requires compliance with the minimum requirements set forth in sections 16-45 and 16-46, issuing authorities shall enforce compliance with the minimum requirements as if a permit had been issued and violations shall be subject to the same penalties as violations by permit holders. (Ord. of 8-12-1996, § III) Secs. 16-21—16-43. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS FOR BEST MANAGEMENT
Sec. 16-44. - General provisions. Excessive soil erosion and resulting sedimentation can take place during land disturbing activities. Therefore, plans for those land disturbing activities which are not excluded by this article shall contain provisions for application of soil erosion and sedimentation control measures and practices. The provisions shall be incorporated into the erosion and sedimentation control measures and practices shall conform to the minimum requirements of sections 16-45 and 16-46. The application of measures and practices shall apply to all features of the site, including street and utility installations, drainage facilities and other temporary and permanent improvements. Measures shall be installed to prevent or control erosion and sedimentation pollution during all stages of any land disturbing activity. (Ord. of 8-12-1996, § IV(A)) Sec. 16-45. - Minimum requirements/BMPs. (a) Best management practices as set forth in this section and section 16-46 shall be required for all land disturbing activities. Proper design, installation, and maintenance of best management practices shall constitute a complete defense to any action by the director or to any other allegation of noncompliance with subsection (b) of this section or any substantially similar terms contained in a permit for the discharge of stormwater issued pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-5-30(f). As used in this subsection, the terms "proper design" and "properly designed" mean designed to control soil erosion and sedimentation for all rainfall events up to and including a 25-year, 24-hour rainfall event.
