(Ord. of 10-12-2010, art. 4, § F) Sec. 16-291. - Standards for critical facilities. (a) Critical facilities shall not be located in the 100-year floodplain or the 500-year floodplain. (b) All ingress and egress from any critical facility must be protected to the 500-year flood elevation. (Ord. of 10-12-2010, art. 4, § G) Secs. 16-292—16-315. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - VARIANCES
Sec. 16-316. - Procedures. (a) The planning and zoning board as established by the City of Reidsville shall hear and decide requests for appeals or variance from the requirements of this article. (b) The planning and zoning board shall hear and decide appeals when it is alleged an error in any requirement, decision, or determination is made by the city building inspector in the enforcement or administration of this article. (c) Any person aggrieved by the decision of the planning and zoning board may appeal such decision to the Superior Court of Tattnall County, as provided in O.C.G.A. § 5-4-1. (d) Variances may be issued for the repair or rehabilitation of historic structures upon a determination that the proposed repair or rehabilitation will not preclude the structure's continued designation as a historic structure and the variance is the minimum to preserve the historic character and design of the structure. (e) Variances may be issued for development necessary for the conduct of a functionally dependent use, provided that the criteria of this article are met, no reasonable alternative exists, and the development is protected by methods that minimize flood damage during the base flood and create no additional threats to public safety. (f) Variances shall not be issued within any designated floodway if any increase in flood levels during the base flood discharge would result. (g) In reviewing such requests, the planning and zoning board shall consider all technical evaluations, relevant factors, and all standards specified in this and other sections of this article. (h) Conditions for variances. (1) A variance shall be issued only when there is: a. A finding of good and sufficient cause; b. A determination that failure to grant the variance would result in exceptional hardship; and c. A determination that the granting of a variance will not result in increased flood heights, additional threats to public safety, extraordinary public expense, create nuisance, cause fraud on or victimization of the public, or conflict with existing local laws or ordinances. (2) The provisions of this article are minimum standards for flood loss reduction; therefore any deviation from the standards must be weighed carefully. Variances shall only be issued upon a determination that the variance is the minimum necessary, considering the flood hazard, to afford relief; and, in the instance of a historic structure, a determination that the variance is the minimum necessary so as not to destroy the historic character and design of the building. (3) Any applicant to whom a variance is granted shall be given written notice specifying the difference between the base flood elevation and the elevation of the proposed lowest floor and stating that the cost of flood insurance will be commensurate with the increased risk to life and property resulting from the reduced lowest floor elevation. (4) The zoning board shall maintain the records of all appeal actions and report any variances to the Federal Emergency Management Agency upon request. Upon consideration of the factors listed above and the purposes of this ordinance, the city planning and zoning board may attach such conditions to the granting of variances as it deems necessary to further the purposes of this article. (Ord. of 10-12-2010, art. 5) Secs. 16-317—16-333. - Reserved. ARTICLE IX. - WELLHEAD PROTECTION
Sec. 16-334. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to ensure the provision of a safe and sanitary drinking water supply for the city by the establishment of wellhead protection zones surrounding the wellheads for all wells which are the supply sources for the city water system and by the designation and regulation of property uses and conditions which may be maintained within such zones. (Ord. of 1-10-1994, § 1) Sec. 16-335. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Hazardous waste or material means any waste or material which, because of its quantity, concentration or physical, chemical or infectious characteristics, may: (1) Cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness; or (2) Pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or to the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, disposed of or otherwise managed. Sanitary landfill means a disposal site where solid wastes, including putrescible wastes, or hazardous wastes are disposed of on land by placing earth cover thereon. Wellhead means the upper terminal of a well, including adapters, ports, seals, valves and other attachments. (Ord. of 1-10-1994, § 2) Sec. 16-336. - Establishment of wellhead protection zone. There is hereby established a use district to be known as a wellhead protection zone, identified and described as all the area within a circle the center of which is the center of any city water supply wellhead and the radius of which is 250 feet. (Ord. of 1-10-1994, § 3) Sec. 16-337. - Permitted uses. The following uses shall be permitted within wellhead protection zones: (1) Any use permitted within existing agricultural or single-family residential lot size for a lot any portion of which lies within the wellhead protection zone shall not be less one acre; and (2) Any other open land use where any building located on the property is incidental and accessory to the primary open land use. (Ord. of 1-10-1994, § 4) Sec. 16-338. - Prohibited uses. The following uses or conditions shall be and are hereby prohibited within wellhead protection zones, whether or not such use or condition may otherwise be ordinarily included as a part of a use permitted under section 16-337: (1) Surface use or storage of hazardous material, expressly including commercial use of agricultural pesticides; (2) Septic tanks or drain fields appurtenant thereto; (3) Impervious surfaces other than roofs or buildings, and streets, driveways and walks serving buildings permitted under section 16-337; (4) Sanitary landfills; (5) Hazardous waste disposal sites; (6) Stormwater infiltration basins; (7) Underground storage tanks; any existing underground storage tanks which are in violation of this article shall be removed at such times and in such manner as required by federal or state law or regulations implemented by the environmental protection agency or the environmental protection division; (8) Sanitary sewer lines within 150 feet of a wellhead. (Ord. of 1-10-1994, § 5) Sec. 16-339. - Administration. The policies and procedures for administration of any wellhead protection zone established under this article, including without limitation those applicable to nonconforming uses, exceptions, enforcement and penalties, shall be the same as provided in the existing zoning ordinance for the city, as the same is presently enacted or may from time to time be amended. (Ord. of 1-10-1994, § 6)

div.head: Chapter 18 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION
div.p:
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Fire prevention and protection generally, O.C.G.A. § 25-1-1 et seq.; local fire departments generally, O.C.G.A. § 25-3-1 et seq.; minimum requirements for local fire departments, O.C.G.A. § 25-3-20 et seq.; authority of local government units to enact fire prevention regulations, O.C.G.A. § 25-3-4; firefighter standards and training, O.C.G.A. § 25-4-1; regulation of blasting generally, O.C.G.A. § 25-8-1 et seq.; regulation of fireworks, O.C.G.A. § 25-10-1 et seq.; volunteer firefighters for counties and municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-23. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 18-1. - Fire protection fees. The city has levied a fire protection fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. The fire prevention fee shall be collected by adding the respective fee to all customer bills for water service from the city. All volunteer firemen shall be exempt from the payment of this fee. (Code 1989, § 3-2-12; Ord. of 12-11-2000) Secs. 18-2—18-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT
Sec. 18-21. - Fire chief and members. The fire department shall be headed by a fire chief and shall be composed of such other paid and volunteer members and employees as may be determined necessary by the city council. (Code 1989, § 3-2-1) Sec. 18-22. - Police authority of firefighters. Whenever the fire department is answering an alarm or operating at the scene of a fire or other emergency, every enrolled member of the department is hereby empowered and authorized to control and direct motor vehicle traffic, stop or move vehicles, and enforce all provisions of this article and any other code provisions, the enforcement of which are deemed necessary to assist in the control of the fire or other emergency. (Code 1989, § 3-2-3) Sec. 18-23. - Interfering with equipment. No person other than a duly enrolled member of the fire department shall ride upon the fire trucks of the city at any time, or use, borrow or interfere with any fire department equipment, or attempt to use the equipment at the scene of a fire unless authorized to do so by the fire chief. (Code 1989, § 3-2-2) Secs. 18-24—18-49. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - FIRE CODE DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 18-50. - Scope. (a) The provisions of this article shall apply to all buildings, structures, premises, facilities, and applicable conditions within the city. They shall apply to existing as well as new buildings, structures, premises, facilities, and applicable conditions and whenever a covered activity creates a distinct hazard from fire or its associated hazards to life or to the property of another. (b) The provisions of this article shall apply in addition to and in supplementation of the provisions of the fire code adopted by reference in section 8-52 (International Fire Code, 2006 Edition). In the event of conflict, the provisions of this article shall control. (Code 1989, § 3-2-7(a)) Secs. 18-51—18-73. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 18-74. - Duties of fire chief. The implementation of these provisions shall be administered by the fire chief, and may be applied or enforced as he deems appropriate and necessary to gain reasonable, realistic, and practical minimum compliance with the purpose and intent of this article within the city. The fire chief is authorized to seek compliance with applicable state fire and life safety standards within the city in accordance with state law, procedures, rules, regulations and orders. (Code 1989, § 3-2-7(b)) Sec. 18-75. - Enforcement assistance. The chief of police, the city building inspector, or law enforcement officers of the city shall render assistance to the fire chief in the implementation and enforcement of this Code upon the request of the fire chief. (Code 1989, § 3-2-7(c)) Sec. 18-76. - Right of entry to conduct inspections. (a) The fire chief or his authorized representatives may, to the extent permitted by law, have free access to and the right to enter at all reasonable times any building, structure, facility or premises coming under the scope of this code, whether completed or under construction, for the purpose of conducting inspections and otherwise implementing the provisions of this article. (b) Before entering any building, structure, facility or premises not normally open to the public, except when a fire or other emergency condition exists or has occurred, the fire chief or his representatives shall obtain the consent of the occupant, owner, or person in charge at the time. Where consent to enter is refused, the fire chief may seek an order or administrative search warrant from the municipal court of the city, or if deemed appropriate, from the superior court of the county authorizing his entry or that of his representatives for the purpose of conducting the inspection or investigation. (c) The term "emergency condition," for purposes of this section, means any condition or circumstance which the fire chief judges to constitute an immediate threat or danger to the occupants of the building, structure, facility or premises or the public or exposed property from fire, explosion or threat of fire or explosion. (Code 1989, § 3-2-7(d)) Sec. 18-77. - Implied consent. Any application for or the acceptance of any approval, permit, license or certificate requested, or required pursuant to this code or applicable law or ordinance of this city or state, constitutes agreement and consent by the person, firm or corporation making the application, or accepting the approval, permit, license or certificate to allow the fire chief or his designees to enter the building, structure or premises at any reasonable time to conduct inspections as may be deemed appropriate by the fire chief or as otherwise provided by this article or other applicable ordinances, regulations or state law. (Code 1989, § 3-2-7(e)) Sec. 18-78. - Inspections. (a) The fire chief is authorized to inspect or cause to be inspected, as resources permit, buildings, structures, premises and facilities coming within the scope of this code, as he deems appropriate or necessary based on fire experience in the community, on complaint, or other applicable grounds, for the purposes of ascertaining if any conditions exist which could be reasonably construed to cause a fire or explosion, or that could contribute to the spread of a fire or its byproducts, or any significant nonconformance with the purposes or provisions of this article or of any other law, rule or regulation affecting safety to the life or property from fire, explosion, or the hazards related to same. (b) The fire chief is authorized to apply other applicable laws, and to cause to be corrected any conditions which could be reasonably construed to cause a fire or explosion, or that could contribute to the spread of a fire, or any significant nonconformance with the purposes or provisions of this code affecting safety to life or property from fire, explosion or to the hazards related to same. (Code 1989, § 3-2-7(f)) Sec. 18-79. - Notice of or order to eliminate dangerous or unlawful conditions. (a) Whenever the fire chief or his designated representatives find any significant violations of this code or any significant fire hazards as defined this code, he is authorized to issue or serve a written notice of the findings of an inspection as set forth in this section. (b) Whenever the fire chief or his designated representatives find any violations of this code or any fire hazards that are deemed to create a serious potential for fire or explosion or which is deemed to create a serious potential threat to life in the event of fire or explosion, he is authorized to issue a written order to correct or abate the violations or hazards. Such order, when issued, shall set forth a reasonable and realistic time or date limit for correction, abatement or compliance. The time for correction, abatement and compliance established by or as directed by the fire chief may be reasonably correlated by him to the seriousness or relative degree of hazard, as determined by him, and or to the complexity of the means of correction or abatement. (c) Where deemed necessary by the fire chief, he may issue a verbal order for immediate correction or abatement followed by a written order or notice of action. (Code 1989, § 3-2-7(g)) Sec. 18-80. - Serving notices or orders. (a) The service of notices or orders issued pursuant to this article may be made by the fire chief or his representatives upon the owner, occupant or person in charge of the building, structure, facility, premises or portion thereof where the hazards or violations were found, or by delivering a copy of the notice or order to any or all of the persons noted. (b) In the event such person or persons cannot be served by delivery as noted, service may be accomplished by affixing a copy of the notice or order in a conspicuous place at or near the entrance of the building, structure, facility or premises, or by delivering or sending a copy of the notice or order to the known agent of the owner or occupant, or in the event of an absentee owner with no known agent, by sending a copy by certified or registered mail to the owner's last known residence, business or post office address. (Code 1989, § 3-2-7(h)) Sec. 18-81. - Failure to comply; penalties; removal of prohibited conditions and violations. (a) Any person who shall fail to comply with an order or correction of abatement issued pursuant to this article, or who shall build or act in violation of this Code or of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved under authority of this Code in connection with any approval, certificate or permit issued thereunder, or who shall perform any act deemed to create a serious potential for fire or explosion and for which the issuance of an order to correct or abate is not adequate, and who is found guilty shall be guilty of a violation of this Code. (b) For each violation and noncompliance, the violator shall be subject to penalties as provided in section 1-14. The imposition of penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue, and the responsible persons shall be required to correct or abate such violations within a time limit as ordered by the court. When not otherwise specified, each five days that a prohibited condition or violation continues following an order of the court to correct or abate same shall constitute a separate offense. (c) When the fire chief or his authorized representative determines that violations of this article warrant the filing of charges or action of the court, the issuing of a citation of charges or summons to appear before the municipal court of the city shall be served by any certified law enforcement officer to the city upon request of the fire chief or his authorized representative. (d) In addition to the filing of charges as authorized by this section, or as a separate remedy at law, the fire chief may seek injunctive relief for any fire hazard, violation, or condition that threatens the safety of life based on the provisions of this article or any applicable ordinance of the city or state law. (e) The application of penalties by the court as provided in this section shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions or violations. (Code 1989, § 3-2-7(i)) Sec. 18-82. - Removal of notices or orders; illegal use of buildings. (a) It is unlawful for any person to remove any notice or order issued in connection with this code and affixed to a building, structure, facility or premises without the approval of the fire chief or his authorized representative. (b) It is unlawful for any persons firm or corporation to use a building, structure, facility or premises in violation of the provisions of this article where an order has been affixed to same prohibiting the use of same under the authority of any provision of this article without the approval of the fire chief or his authorized representative or the court. (Code 1989, § 3-2-7(j)) Sec. 18-83. - Summary abatement. The fire chief shall have the authority to summarily abate any violation of this code or any fire hazard as defined by this article which constitutes an immediate or imminent danger or threat to life in his opinion, and where following the provisions for abating corrective action or abatement as set forth elsewhere in this article is not practical in his judgment. (Code 1989, § 3-2-7(k)) Sec. 18-84. - Modifications and appeals. (a) The fire chief shall have the authority to modify or waive any of the provisions of this article, or of the ordinances or standards adopted by reference as supplements to the provisions of this article, upon application in writing by the owners or occupants of a buildings, structure, facility or premises, or by his designated authorized agents, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of this code or the codes or standards adopted by reference as supplements to the provisions of this article. (b) Such modification or waiver may be granted by the fire chief, provided that in his judgment the spirit, intents and purposes of this article are observed, the public safety shall be reasonably and practically secured, the waiver or modification is in the interest of the community and substantial justice will be done. The particulars of any waiver or modification granted or allowed, and the decision of the fire chief thereon, shall be entered upon the records of the fire department. (Code 1989, § 3-2-7(l)) Sec. 18-85. - Interference with fire officials. It is unlawful for any person to interfere with, abuse, or obstruct in any way the fire chief, or his representatives in carrying out any actions in accordance with their official duties as set forth by this article or by any other applicable local ordinances, or by state law or regulation. (Code 1989, § 3-2-7(m)) Sec. 18-86. - Authority to investigate fires, explosions, false alarms or related incidents. (a) The fire chief or his authorized representatives are authorized to investigate the cause, origin and circumstances of any fire or explosion, or to investigate any incident resulting from a false alarm or fire or a bomb threat. (b) When, in the judgment of the fire chief, reasonable cause exists that a fire or explosion may have been of criminal origin, the fire chief or his authorized representatives are authorized to locate and take custody of any or all physical evidence relating to the cause of the fire or explosion and to continue the investigation to the extent deemed appropriate within the limits of fire department resources and within the limits of applicable state law. (c) The fire chief shall inform the police department of each fire of criminal or suspected criminal origin and he shall assist the police department in its investigation if so requested by that department. The police department shall be responsible for the investigation of fires, explosions, false alarms or bomb threats of criminal origin or suspected criminal origin so as to identify, apprehend and assist in the prosecution of the persons responsible for the criminal acts. (Code 1989, § 3-2-7(n)) Sec. 18-87. - Administrative and municipal liability. (a) Any officer or employee of the city empowered or authorized to administer or act under the provisions of this article, and acting for the city in the discharge of his duties, shall not be held liable personally, and he is hereby relieved from all personal liability from any damages that may accrue to any persons or property as a result of any act required, implied or permitted in the discharge of his duties, or as required, implied or permitted by this article, or as a result of the omission of any action required or authorized by this article. Any suit instituted against any officer or employee in connection with the implementation of the provisions of this article or in connection with any omission to carry out the provisions of this article shall be defended by the legal representative of the city until the matter is settled. (b) The city shall not be liable for any damage to persons or property resulting from any act or any failure to act in connection with any provision of this article. (Code 1989, § 3-2-7(o)) Sec. 18-88. - Evacuation of buildings, structures, facilities or premises. When, in the judgment of the fire chief, or his authorized representatives in his absence, there is an actual or serious potential danger to the occupants or persons in close proximity of any building, structure, facility or premises because of an unsafe structural condition, the presence of explosives, explosive fumes or vapor, toxic fumes, gases or materials, the fire chief, or his authorized representatives in his absence, may order the complete or partial immediate evacuation of the building, structure, facility or premises and, as necessary, areas in such proximity to these as to be endangered. All persons under order to evacuate shall promptly leave the evacuation area and shall not reenter until authorized to do so by the official that issued the evacuation order. (Code 1989, § 3-2-7(q)) Sec. 18-89. - Maintaining a fire hazard, fire nuisance or public nuisance. No person shall knowingly maintain a fire hazard, fire nuisance or a public nuisance as defined by this article and to knowingly maintain such is unlawful. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(a)) Sec. 18-90. - Spread of fire. No person shall knowingly permit or allow any fire to spread so as to endanger the life or property of another or use or operate any device or appliance which may be a source of ignition in any way so as to endanger life or property. No such device or appliance shall be used unless proper removal of combustible or flammable material surrounding the operation is accomplished or such other reasonable precautions are taken to ensure against the starting and spreading of fire. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(b)) Sec. 18-91. - Bonfires and outdoor rubbish fires. (a) No person shall kindle or maintain any bonfire or rubbish or any fire for the disposal of leaves, cut brush, etc., or authorize any such fire to be kindled or maintained on any public street or land. No such fire shall be kindled or maintained on any private land unless the location is not less that 50 feet of any building or structure, or the fire is contained in an approved waste burner located safely not less than 30 feet from any building or structure. (b) Bonfires, rubbish fires or other outdoor fires shall be constantly attended by a competent and able-bodied person until such fire is extinguished. Such person shall have a garden hose connected to the water supply and readily available for use. (c) The fire chief may prohibit or require the extinguishment of any or all bonfires, rubbish fires or other outdoor fires when atmospheric conditions or local circumstances make such fires a fire hazard or a fire nuisance. (d) No person shall kindle or maintain any fire which produces offensive, noxious or toxic smoke, fumes, vapors or odors. Such fires and their byproducts are deemed to be a fire nuisance. Upon complaint of any person regarding smoke, fumes, vapors or odors from outdoor burning being conducted with or without a permit or other proper authorization, the person responsible for kindling or maintaining such fire shall promptly extinguish same or cause same to be extinguished upon verbal notice or order of the fire chief or his representative. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(c)) Sec. 18-92. - Kindling of fire on land of another. No person shall kindle a fire upon the land of another without the permission of the owner thereof or his agent. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(d)) Sec. 18-93. - Hot ashes and other dangerous materials. No person shall deposit hot ashes, cinders, smoldering coals or substances subject to spontaneous ignition into any combustible receptacle, or place same within ten feet of any combustible materials; provided, however, the distance may be reduced to three feet if such materials are in a substantial metal container with a metal cover. Such container, unless resting on a noncombustible floor or on the ground outside the building, shall be placed in a noncombustible stand. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(e)) Sec. 18-94. - Notifying the fire department. (a) Whenever an unfriendly fire occurs in any building, structure or on any premises of any kind, the owner, manager, or any person discovering the fire, upon discovery of the fire or of evidence of there having been an unfriendly fire, even though it has apparently been extinguished, shall immediately cause notice of the existence of such fire, the circumstances of same and the location of same to be given to the city fire department. (b) This requirement shall not be construed to forbid the owner, manager or other person in control of the aforementioned building or premises from using all reasonable diligence necessary to extinguish such fire while or after notification of it prior to the arrival of the fire department. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(f)) Sec. 18-95. - Unlawful to restrict the reporting of fire or emergencies. It is unlawful for any person to make, issue, post or maintain any regulation, rule, order or policy, written or verbal, that would require any person to take any unnecessary delaying action prior to reporting a fire or related emergency or hazardous condition to the city fire department. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(g)) Sec. 18-96. - Reporting a hazardous condition. Any person, upon discovering evidence of spontaneous heating or other abnormal heating of any merchandise, commodity, cargo, shipment or other material of any kind in any building, structure, appliance, apparatus, tank, vehicle, stack, pile or marine vessel, or any person discovering or being appraised of any uncontrolled leak or spill of a hazardous gas, liquid or other material, shall immediately notify the city police department. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(h)) Sec. 18-97. - Barricading vacant buildings. Any persons owning or having charge or control over any vacant building, including dwellings, shall remove all combustible waste, refuse, rubbish, or trash therefrom, and shall lock, barricade or otherwise secure all windows, doors and other openings in the building to prohibit entry by unauthorized persons. The premises shall be maintained clear of any waste, rubbish or hazardous material. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(i)) Sec. 18-98. - Use of torches or open flame. (a) Use of torches or open flame for the removal of paint, or sweating pipe joints or for other purposes. Any person using a torch or other flame-producing device for removing paint from any building or structure or from any object within any building or structure, or for sweating pipe joints or for other purposes, shall be responsible for providing at least one approved fire extinguisher having at least a 2A classification or a water hose connected to a reliable water supply in the area where the open flame is being used. (b) The person shall also be responsible for providing a fire watcher to remain at the building or structure to check for evidence of fire for at least one hour after the torch or flame-producing device has been used. When using any torch or other flame-producing device, combustible material in close proximity of the flame or device shall be protected against ignition by shielding, wetting or other reasonable and realistic means. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(j)) Sec. 18-99. - Hazardous warning lights. It is unlawful to maintain any device utilizing an open flame at any excavation, road or any place where the dislodgment of such device might permit same to roll, fall or slide onto any forest or any land containing combustible material. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(k)) Sec. 18-100. - False fire or emergency alarms; damage to fire alarm equipment. (a) For the purposes of this article, a fire or emergency alarm shall be deemed and construed as being any act as follows: the giving, signaling, transmitting or communicating to any fire station, fire company, building occupants, or to any officer or employees thereof, whether by telephone, spoken word or other means of information or a signal to the effect that there is a fire or other emergency at or near the place indicated by the person giving, signaling, transmitting or communicating such information. (b) It is unlawful for any person to give, signal, transmit or communicate or for any person to cause or permit or conspire with another to be given, signaled, transmitted or communicated in any manner any false fire or emergency alarm. (c) It is unlawful for any person to tamper with or maliciously injure any fire or emergency alarm equipment, public or private, installed and maintained for the purpose of transmitting fire or emergency alarms for occupant notification or for transmitting fire or emergency alarms to the city fire department or other emergency service agency or organization that responds to emergency incidents in the city. (d) Nothing in this article shall prohibit the sounding of any such signal essential for the carrying on of any fire or emergency drill. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(l)) Sec. 18-101. - Asphalt or tar kettles. It is unlawful to transport or permit to be transported any asphalt or tar kettle beneath which is maintained any open fire, heated coals or ashes over any highway, road or street. Asphalt or tar kettles shall not be used inside of or on the roof of any building, or within ten feet of any building. Asphalt or tar kettles shall be in good working order and complete with an operation kettle lid. There shall be at least one approved portable fire extinguisher of a minimum 20B classification within 50 feet of each asphalt or tar kettle during the period such kettle is in use and one additional portable fire extinguisher of a least such classification on the roof being covered. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(m)) Sec. 18-102. - Heating appliances, chimneys, vents, flues. (a) All new heating appliances, chimneys, incinerators, smokestacks, flues, or similar devices for producing heat, or for conveying smoke or hot gases to the outer air shall be installed, constructed, used and maintained in accordance with their listing, in accordance with the building code, mechanical code or gas code, or when not covered by such codes, with the applicable standards of this chapter and the fire code adopted in section 8-52. (b) Existing installations may be continued in service subject to approval by the authority having jurisdiction. The fire chief may request the city gas and heating inspector, director of code enforcement or building official, as designated by the city council, to evaluate the installations to determine what additions or modifications must be made to reasonably ensure the installations meet a reasonable minimum level of safety so as not to create a fire hazard. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(n)) Sec. 18-103. - Commercial cooking equipment. Commercial cooking equipment for the new buildings, structures or occupancies shall be installed, protected and maintained in accordance with the fire code adopted by the city in section 8-52. Existing installations may be continued in service, subject to approval of the fire chief. If deemed necessary, the fire chief may require the installation of safety features deemed appropriate to reasonably ensure the cooking equipment meets a reasonable minimum level of safety so as not to create a fire hazard which endangers safety to life. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(o)) Sec. 18-104. - Electrical wiring and equipment. Electrical wiring, equipment, fixtures and devices shall be installed, used and maintained in accordance with the electrical code or as appropriate the applicable standards of the fire code adopted by the city in section 8-52. Existing installations may be continued in service, subject to approval of the fire chief. If deemed necessary, the fire chief may request the city electrical inspector to inspect the installation to determine what additions or modifications must be made to reasonably ensure the installation meets a reasonable minimum level of safety so as not to create a fire hazard. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(p)) Sec. 18-105. - Air conditioning and ventilating equipment and systems and ductwork. Air conditioning and ventilating equipment, systems and related equipment newly installed shall be installed in accordance with the building code or mechanical code or when appropriate the applicable standards of the fire code adopted by the city in section 8-52. Existing installations may be continued in service, subject to approval by the fire chief if in his judgment a reasonable minimum level of safety is provided so as not to create a fire hazard. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(q)) Sec. 18-106. - Firewalls, fire doors, smoke-stop barriers. (a) Firewalls, fire stops and fire related partitions and floors required by this article, the building code or other applicable codes or laws shall be properly maintained. All openings made therein for the passages of pipes, electrical conduit, wiring and the like, and holes made for any reason shall be sealed with approved noncombustible material to protect against the passage of smoke or fire. Openings shall be protected in accordance with the applicable standards of the fire code adopted by the city in section 8-52. (b) All the fire doors and smoke-stop doors shall be maintained in an operable condition. No fire door may be blocked, tied, obstructed or otherwise made inoperable. The use of door stops, wedges and other unapproved hold-open devices are prohibited. Where it is desired to keep the doors open, the fire chief may require the installation of approved smoke activated self-closing devices or, if appropriate, heat activated. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(r)) Sec. 18-107. - Required access for fire apparatus. (a) Any premises which the city fire department may be called upon to protect in case of fire or other emergency, and which is not readily accessible from public roads or to which access may be obstructed by parked vehicles, shall be provided with suitable access roads, fire lanes, gates, etc., so that all buildings on the premises are reasonably accessible to fire apparatus. (b) Fire lanes shall be provided and adequately and clearly indicated for each commercial and public building by the owner or occupant of same when the need for a fire lane is determined to exist by the fire chief. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(s)) Sec. 18-108. - Obstructing fire hydrants. (a) No person shall place or keep any fence, growth, trash or other material near any fire hydrant that would prevent such hydrant from being immediately discernible or in any other manner hinder the fire department from gaining immediate access to a fire hydrant. (b) No authorized person shall use or operate any fire hydrant or any valve installed on any water system intended for use of the fire department for fire suppression or control purposes and which is accessible to any public highway, alley or private way open to or generally used by the public unless such person first secures proper authorization. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(t)) Sec. 18-109. - Tampering with barriers, seals, etc. No person, unless properly authorized, shall remove, unlock, destroy, tamper with or otherwise molest in any manner any lock, gate, door, barricade, chain, enclosure, sign, tag, notice or seal which has been lawfully installed by the fire chief or by his order or under his control. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(u)) Sec. 18-110. - General dangerous conditions. No person, firm or corporation shall permit or maintain any of the conditions noted herein or any other condition that might create a fire hazard and that might endanger life or property from fire or its byproducts: (1) Dangerous or unlawful amounts of combustible or explosive or otherwise hazardous material; (2) Hazardous conditions arising from defective or improperly installed equipment for handling or using combustible or explosive or otherwise hazardous material; (3) Dangerous accumulations of rubbish, waste paper, boxes, shavings or other highly combustible material; (4) Accumulations of dust or waste material in air conditioning or ventilating systems or of grease in kitchen or other exhaust ducts or inadequate clearances to unprotected combustible material from hoods, grease extractors and ducts; and (5) Obstructions to or on fire escapes, designated access openings in exterior walls for fire department use, stairs, passageways, doors or windows liable to interfere with the egress of the occupants in event of fire or emergency or with the operations of the city fire department. (Code 1989, § 3-2-8(v)) Sec. 18-111. - Control of combustible and flammable materials. (a) Accumulations of combustible or flammable waste or refuse. Any person having control of any building, structure, facility, premises, or portion thereof, shall not allow or permit any combustible or flammable waste material or refuse to accumulate in any room, area or space in or on the building, structure, facility or premises in any manner so as to create a fire hazard or hazard to life or property in event of fire originating in or spreading to such an accumulation. (b) Disposal of combustible or flammable waste or refuse. (1) Any person having control of any building, structure, facility, premises, or portion thereof, shall be responsible for properly disposing of or properly storing combustible or flammable waste or refuse at the end of each working day. This disposal or proper storing shall occur before vacating the building, structure, facility, premises, or portion thereof, and whenever such may be necessary to prevent a fire hazard or other unsafe condition. (2) All combustible or flammable waste, refuse, rubbish, oily rags or oily wastes at work spaces or areas during the day or work period shall be stored in metal, metal lined or approved rigid nonmetallic containers or receptacles. If the wastes, rags or refuse are subject to spontaneous heating or ignition, such shall be kept in metal or metal lined containers with tightfitting self-closing covers. (3) Outdoor accumulations of combustible or flammable waste, refuse, litter and vegetation. Roofs, courts, yards and open spaces shall be kept free and clear of deposits or accumulations of waste paper, hay, grass, straw, weeds, old vehicle tires, combustible litter, rubbish, waste or refuse of any kind that creates a fire hazard as defined in this Code. (Code 1989, § 3-2-9) Sec. 18-112. - Control of smoking. (a) Smoking defined. For the purposes of this section and other provisions of this Code related to smoking, the term "smoking" shall be construed to mean and include the carrying of a lighted pipe, cigar, cigarette or any other device containing tobacco, or any other material for the purpose of inhaling or drawing the smoke or fumes from the glowing or smoldering material. (b) Authority of fire chief. Where conditions are such as to make smoking a fire hazard in any building, structure or facility or on any premises, the fire chief is empowered to order the prohibiting of smoking and to order the posting of "NO SMOKING" signs in each room, space, area, building, structure, facility or premises in or on which smoking shall be prohibited. It is unlawful for any person to smoke where smoking is prohibited by order of the fire chief or his authorized representative during any emergency control operation. (c) Safe smoking areas. The fire chief is empowered to approve locations where smoking is to be permitted, if he deems such to be appropriate, in any building, structure or facility or on any premises. (d) Warning signs. The lettering, size, color and location of legally required "NO SMOKING" signs shall be subject to the approval of the fire chief. It is unlawful for any person to remove, mutilate or destroy any legally required "NO SMOKING" sign. (e) Smoking restricted. It is unlawful for any person to smoke, throw or deposit any lighted or smoldering substance in any place where "NO SMOKING" signs are posted by order of the fire chief or where smoking would clearly constitute a hazard to life or property from fire. (f) Outdoor smoking restrictions. It is unlawful for any person to light, ignite or otherwise set fire to or to smoke any tobacco or other substance or any cigarette, pipe, cigar or other device in or upon any brush or forest-covered land, or land covered with any flammable or combustible material, or upon any road or trail traversing any such land during any period of the year declared by the fire chief as hazardous due to dry conditions or atmospheric conditions, or at any time a hazard exists due to the spill or leakage of a hazardous material in the judgment of the fire chief or his representatives. (g) Smoking in bed unlawful. It is unlawful for any person to smoke in bed in any hotel, motel or dormitory so as to cause a fire due to the careless use of smoking materials in any hotel, motel or dormitory. (h) Disposal of smoking materials. Cigarette, cigars, pipe tobacco or other substances used in pipes, or matches shall not be discarded after use in any trash can, garbage can, waste or refuse container or in any trash or laundry chute. Such material shall be placed in proper ashtrays or other receptacles designated for the discard of used smoking materials and shall not be emptied into any trash chute or trash bin. The contents of ashtrays or receptacles designated for the proper discard of smoking material shall be emptied into covered metal containers or devices and such materials shall be wetted and checked to ensure they are completely extinguished of all glowing or smoldering prior to final disposal. The term "final disposal after being wetted and checked" may include emptying the materials into containers for the removal and disposal of other trash. (Code 1989, § 3-2-10) Sec. 18-113. - Building design and use standards. (a) Every building and structure coming within the scope of this code shall be designed, constructed and maintained so as to provide adequate warning of a fire and so as to provide adequate and protected means of egress for occupants in the event of fire or other emergency or to provide reasonable areas of protective refuge in buildings where egress may not be practical under emergency conditions. (b) In the case of existing buildings or structures, the fire chief may modify the provisions of the adopted life safety code pertaining to existing buildings or structures when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code; provided, however, the spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety reasonably protected, and substantial justice done. The particulars of such modification when granted or allowed, and the decision of the fire chief thereon shall be entered upon the records of the fire department. (c) In every building or structure where seats, tables, merchandise, equipment, numbers of people or similar impediments to egress are present, required aisles, corridors, passages and other means of egress shall be maintained free of impediments to emergency egress. (Code 1989, § 3-2-11(a)—(c)) Sec. 18-114. - Overcrowding buildings. (a) In any building or portion of a building or structure used as a place of assembly, as defined by the life safety code, or in other buildings or structures or portions thereof as required by the building code, the number of occupants thereof shall not be permitted to exceed the allowed or posted capacity established by the fire chief or the building official. (b) For purposes of this section, it shall be prima facie evidence of an overcrowding condition when either there are more people in the building or portion thereof than has been allowed or posted, or when, in the judgment of the fire chief or his representative, a threat to the safety of life exists due to the number of persons sitting or standing so as to obstruct or impede the use of aisles, passages, corridors or exits. (c) It is the responsibility of the owner, manager or person in charge of a building, structure, or portion thereof, to prevent an overcrowding condition to exist and to take prompt action to remedy an overcrowding condition when so advised or ordered by the fire chief or his representative. It is unlawful for the owner, manager or person thereof, to knowingly permit an overcrowding condition to exist. (Code 1989, § 3-2-11(d))

div.head: Chapter 20 - HEALTH AND PUBLIC WELFARE
div.p: (RESERVED)

div.head: Chapter 22 - LAW ENFORCEMENT
div.p:
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Law enforcement generally, O.C.G.A. § 35-1-1 et seq.; compensation of law enforcement officers on commission basis prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-9; dispatch centers to have trained communications officers on staff, O.C.G.A. § 36-26-19. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 22-1. - Resisting arrest, rescues, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to resist any police officer while he is attempting to make an arrest in the city, or to rescue or attempt to rescue a prisoner in the custody of police officer or officers of said city, and any person violating the provisions of this ordinance shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-14. (Code 1989, § 3-1-3) Sec. 22-2. - Refusal to assist officers. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to fail to refuse to assist police officers of the city, when called upon by said officer or officers to assist in making an arrest or to suppress disorderly or riotous conduct in said city, and any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-14. (Code 1989, § 3-1-4) Secs. 22-3—22-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT
Sec. 22-23. - Composition of police department. The police department shall consist of those officers and employees of those ranks and positions as approved by the city council. (Code 1989, § 3-1-1) Sec. 22-24. - Responsibilities. The department shall be responsible for patrol, traffic control, investigation of accidents, investigation of crimes, apprehension of offenders, court appearances, security of business establishments and for any other matters of public safety and law enforcement as directed by the city council. (Code 1989, § 3-1-2)

div.head: Chapter 24 - OFFENSES AND NUISANCES
div.p:
FOOTNOTE(S): --- (1) --- State Law reference— Crimes generally, O.C.G.A. § 16-1-1 et seq.; maximum penalties that may be imposed by municipalities, O.C.G.A. §§ 36-35-6, 36-32-1, 36-32-5; additional penalties and bond in certain criminal and traffic cases, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-73; authority to impose community service as punishment, O.C.G.A. § 17-10-1; alternative sentences by municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-5; powers of municipal court judges in criminal cases, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-3; nuisances generally, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1 et seq.; jurisdiction of municipal and magistrate courts regarding nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-12-5; misdemeanor nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-6; placement of posters, signs, and advertisements on public or private property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-58; abatement of nuisances generally, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7 et seq.; dogs as nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-7; unlawful junkyards as nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-246. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 24-1. - Tampering with alarm system. It is unlawful for any person or persons to willfully, maliciously or mischievously interfere or tamper with any fire alarm box or any of the appliances or apparatus connected therewith, located within the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1989, § 3-2-4) Sec. 24-2. - False fire alarm. It is unlawful for any person or persons to knowingly make a false report of fire, which report shall reach the employees of the city, and thus cause the fire whistle to be blown. (Code 1989, § 3-2-5) State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-26 et seq. Sec. 24-3. - Driving over fire hose. Anyone driving over fire hose in a roadway will be fined the costs of hose damage plus $50.00. (Code 1989, § 3-2-6) Sec. 24-4. - Disorderly conduct. It is unlawful and disorderly conduct for any person to: (1) Act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another, whereby a reasonable person would be placed in fear of safety for life or limb; (2) Place the property of another in serious danger of being destroyed or damaged; (3) Use fighting words directed toward another, who becomes outraged and thus creates a turmoil; (4) Violently interfere with another's pursuit of a lawful occupation; or (5) Congregate with others to halt the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic and refuse to clear the way when ordered by lawful authority to do so. (Code 1989, § 9-1-1) State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-39. Sec. 24-5. - Loitering on private premises. It is unlawful for any person to lurk about the premises and near the private habitations of other persons. (Code 1989, § 9-1-2) State Law reference— Loitering or prowling, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-36. Sec. 24-6. - Public drunkenness. It is unlawful for any person to be on the streets of the city or in any public place in an intoxicated condition. (Code 1989, § 9-1-3) State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41. Sec. 24-7. - Posting signs on poles without consent. It is unlawful for any person to post or display in or upon any bridge any sign or advertisement, or to post or display upon any telegraph, telephone or electric company's pole, or upon any public property or the private property of any person any bills, signs or advertisement without the consent in writing of the owner thereof. (Code 1989, § 9-1-5) State Law reference— Damaging municipal property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25. Sec. 24-8. - Weapons; discharge in city. It is unlawful for any person to discharge a firearm, including pistol, rifle and shotgun, or to shoot an air gun, including BB gun and pellet gun, within the city, except by law enforcement officers in the line of duty, and the military when on drill or parade, or at a funeral in honor of the dead; provided, however, it shall not be unlawful for any person to shoot a BB gun upon private property if that person shall have first obtained the express permission of the owner of that property to do so. (Code 1989, § 9-1-6) State Law reference— Discharge of firearms, O.C.G.A. §§ 16-11-103, 16-11-104. Sec. 24-9. - Interfering with property used in the distribution of utilities. (a) It is unlawful for any person intentionally and without authority to injure or destroy any meter, pipe, conduit, wire, line, post, lamp, or other apparatus belonging to a company, or to the city engaged in the manufacture or sale of electricity, gas, water, telephone, or other public services, or intentionally and without authority to prevent a meter from properly registering the quantity of such service supplied, or in any way to interfere with the proper action of such company or the city, intentionally to divert any services of such company of the city, or otherwise intentionally and without the consent of such company or the city, any service manufactured, sold, or distributed by such company of the city. (b) Where there is no evidence to the contrary, the person performing any of the illegal acts prohibited by this section or the person, who with knowledge of such violation receives the benefit of such service without proper charge as a result of such improper action shall be presumed to be responsible for such acts of tampering or diversion. (Code 1989, § 9-1-9) State Law reference— Damaging municipal property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25. Sec. 24-10. - Reckless driving. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons operating an automobile, truck, motorcycle, or other motor driven vehicles to drive in a careless or reckless manner in the city. (Code 1989, § 8-2-5) Sec. 24-11. - Gambling devices and places prohibited. (a) Gambling devices, as that term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-20, are prohibited in the city, and the ownership, use, or transport thereof shall be a misdemeanor pursuant to state law, except as exempted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35. (b) Gambling places, as that term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-20 are prohibited in the city, and the operation thereof shall be a misdemeanor pursuant to state law. (Ord. of 11-10-2011, §§ 1, 2) Secs. 24-12—24-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES INVOLVING MINORS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 24-41. - Poolrooms; minors prohibited. It is unlawful for any person who operates a billiard parlor or poolroom in the city to allow any person less than 16 years of age to enter billiard parlors or poolrooms in the city, unless accompanied by a parent or guardian. (Code 1989, § 7-6-4) Secs. 24-42—24-70. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - CURFEW
Sec. 24-71. - Purpose. (a) The city has determined that there has been an increase in juvenile violence and crime by persons under the age of 18 in the city resulting in juveniles being involved in a wide range of unacceptable behavior by juveniles; that persons under the age of 18 are particularly susceptible by their lack of maturity and experience to participate in unlawful activity and to be victims of older perpetrators of crime; that there has been a significant breakdown in the supervision and guidance normally provided by parents for minors resulting in an increase in the crimes, substance abuse, and school dropout rates, juvenile pregnancy, and other illicit behavior. (b) The city has an obligation to provide for the protection of minors from each other and from other persons, for the enforcement of parental control over and responsibility for children, for the protection of the general public, and for the reduction of the incidence of juvenile criminal activities which are not easily controlled by existing laws and ordinances. (c) The city has determined a curfew for those under the age of 18 will be in the interest of the public health, safety, and general welfare and will help to attain the foregoing objectives and to diminish the undesirable impact of such conduct on the citizens of the city and will promote the public good, safety and welfare. (d) Parental responsibility for the whereabouts of children is the accepted norm, and legal sanctions to enforce such responsibility have had demonstrated effectiveness in many cities. The city has determined that curfew regulations will increase parental responsibility for minors within their control and decrease minor delinquency. (Ord. of 2-11-2008, § 3-3-1) Sec. 24-72. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Emergency errand means a mission that results from an unforeseen combination of circumstances that call for immediate action. The term "emergency errand" includes, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, or automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. Minor means any unemancipated person under the age of 18. Public place means any place to which the public has access and includes, but is not limited to, streets, highways, alleys or rights-of-way, to include sidewalks, parks, playgrounds, or other places or buildings open to the public; any cemeteries, school yards, bodies of water or watercourses; any privately or publicly owned places of amusement, entertainment or public accommodation, including parking lots; and any vacant lot or land. (Ord. of 2-11-2008, § 3-3-2) Sec. 24-73. - Curfew hours; exceptions. It is unlawful for any minor under the age of 18 years to loiter, wander, stroll, or play in any public place unsupervised by his parent, legal guardian, or other adult over the age of 21, having the lawful care and custody of the minor and having the lawful authority to be at such places between the hours of 11:00 p.m. on any day and 5:00 a.m. of the following day; provided, however, that on Fridays and Saturdays, the evening curfew shall begin at 12:00 midnight rather than 11:00 p.m.; and provided further that the provisions of this section shall not apply in the following instances: (1) When the minor is upon an emergency errand directed by his parent, guardian, or other adult person 21 years of age or older having the lawful care and custody of the minor; (2) When the minor is returning directly home from a school activity; (3) When the minor is traveling to, or returning directly home from, lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in above-referenced places during the proscribed period of time; (4) When the minor is attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of First Amendment rights of free speech, freedom of assembly, or free exercise of religion; (5) When the minor is engaged in interstate and intrastate vehicular travel through the city with parental consent; (6) When the minor is on the sidewalk adjoining the property where the minor resides or on either side of or across the street from the property where the minor resides and the adult owner or resident of that property has given permission for the minor to be there; and (7) When the minor is married or has been married pursuant to state law. (Ord. of 2-11-2008, § 3-3-3) Sec. 24-74. - Responsibility of person having custody of child under 18. It is unlawful for the parent, guardian, or other person having custody or control of any child under the age of 18 years, to permit, or by insufficient control, to allow such minor to violate this article. A person charged with violation of this section for the first time shall be given a warning citation. Upon subsequent violation, the person shall be charged with such violation and, if found guilty, such person shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-14. (Ord. of 2-11-2008, § 3-3-4) Sec. 24-75. - Jurisdiction for violations by minors. Any minor under the age of 17 years who violates this article shall be subject to the jurisdiction of the juvenile court. Any minor 17 years of age who violates this article shall be subject to the jurisdiction of the municipal court. (Ord. of 2-11-2008, § 3-3-5) Secs. 24-76—24-93. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - NUISANCES FOOTNOTE(S): --- (2) --- State Law reference— Nuisances generally, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1 et seq.; jurisdiction of municipal and magistrate courts regarding nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-12-5; misdemeanor nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-6; placement of posters, signs, and advertisements on public or private property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-58; abatement of nuisances generally, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7 et seq.; dogs as nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-7; unlawful junkyards as nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-246. DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 24-94. - Purpose. (a) The purpose of this article is to exercise the police power in relation to public nuisances and abatement of such nuisances, to protect the public health, safety and welfare, and to promote the economic development of the city. It is also the purpose of this article to prevent and prohibit those conditions which reduce the value of private property, interfere with enjoyment of public and private property, create and constitute fire and other safety and health hazards, and generally create a menace to the health and welfare of the public and contribute to the degradation of the character of neighborhoods and depreciation of property values. (b) It is necessary for the public health, safety and welfare to regulate, prevent and prohibit conditions which may constitute disorderly, disturbing, unsafe, unsanitary, fly-producing, rat-harboring or disease-causing places, conditions or objects. It is also necessary for the public social and economic welfare to regulate, prevent and prohibit conditions that degrade the city's scenic attractiveness and livability and its economic development. (Code 1989, § 9-2-1; Ord. of 4-11-2005, § II(9-2-1); Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-1)) Sec. 24-95. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Abate means to repair, replace, remove, destroy or otherwise remedy the condition in question by such means and in such a manner and to such an extent as the enforcement officer, in his judgment, determines is necessary in the interest of the general health, safety and welfare of the community. Blighted property means any property on which there exists any one or more of the following conditions or activities: (1) A building or structure that is not occupied, inhabited, used, or secured. For purposes of this article, a building or structure is unsecured when it is unlocked or the public can gain entry without the consent of the owner. (2) Any partially constructed, reconstructed or demolished building or structure upon which work is abandoned. Work is deemed abandoned when there is no valid and current building or demolition permit or when there has not been any substantial work on the project for six months. (3) Property which is in an unsecured state so as to potentially constitute an attraction to children, a harbor for vagrants, criminals, or other unauthorized persons, or so as to enable persons to resort thereto for the purpose of committing a nuisance or unlawful act. (4) Any building or other structure which by reason of rot, weakened joints, walls, floors, underpinning, roof, ceilings, or insecure foundation, or other cause has become dilapidated or deteriorated. (5) Any building or other structure with exterior walls or roof coverings that have become so deteriorated as to not provide adequate weather protection and be likely to, or have resulted in, termite infestation or dry rot. (6) Buildings or structures including, but not limited to, walls, windows, fences, signs, substantially defaced to the extent that the disrepair visually impacts on neighboring property or presents a risk to public safety. For purposes of this article the term "defaced" includes, but is not limited to, writings, inscriptions, figures, scratches, or other markings commonly referred to as "graffiti" and peeling, flaking, blistering, or otherwise deteriorated paint. (7) Property which is not kept clean and sanitary and free from all accumulations of offensive matter or odor including, but not limited to, overgrown or dead or decayed trees weeds or other vegetation, rank growth, dead organic matter, rubbish, junk, garbage, animal intestinal waste and urine, and toxic or otherwise hazardous liquids and substances and materials. (8) Property which constitutes a fire hazard or a condition considered dangerous to the public health, safety, and general welfare. (9) Property which is likely to or does harbor rats or other vermin, feral pets, or other non-domesticated animal nuisances. (10) Property which substantially detracts from the aesthetic and economic values of neighboring properties including, but not limited to, personal property and wares and foodstuffs, premises garbage and refuse receptacles, and commercial and industrial business activities which are inadequately buffered from any street, sidewalk, or other publicly trafficked area or such buffering which is inadequately maintained. (11) Landscaping which is inadequately maintained or which is not installed as required by city codes or any permit issued in accordance with such codes. (12) Matter including, but not limited to, smoke, odors, dust, dirt, debris, fumes, and sprays which are permitted to be transported by wind or otherwise upon any street, course, alley, sidewalk, yard, park, or other public or private property and which are determined to be a violation of federal, state, regional, or local air quality regulations. (13) Property including, but not limited to, building facade, window, doorway, driveway, walkway, fence, wall, landscaped planter or area, sidewalk, curb and gutter, and edge of street pavement on which dirt, litter, vegetation, garbage, refuse, debris, flyers, or circulars have accumulated. (14) Property on which a swimming pool, pond, stream, or other body of water which is abandoned, unattended, unfiltered, or not otherwise maintained, resulting in the water becoming polluted. The term "polluted water" is defined for the purpose of this article, as water which contains bacterial growth, remains of garbage, refuse, debris, papers and any other foreign matter or material which constitutes an unhealthy or unsafe condition. (15) Parking lots, driveways, paths, and other areas used or intended to be used for commercial and industrial business activities including, but not limited to, selling, manufacturing, processing, packaging, fabricating, treating, dismantling, processing, transferring, handling, transporting, storing, compounding, or assembling which are inadequately maintained and pose a risk of harm to public health or safety including, but not limited to, unpaved surfaces which generate fugitive dust and paved surfaces with cracks, potholes, or other breaks. (16) Property which is not securely fenced or adequately lighted to prevent illegal access and activity related to the dumping of garbage, waste, debris and litter. (17) Property having a topography, geology, or configuration which, as a result of grading operations, erosion control, sedimentation control work, or other improvements to the property, causes erosion, subsidence, unstable soil conditions, or surface or subsurface drainage problems as to harm or pose a risk of harm to adjacent properties. (18) Property whereon any condition or object obscures the visibility of public street intersections to the public so as to constitute a hazard, including, but not limited to, landscaping, fencing, signs, posts, or equipment. (19) Conditions which, due to their accessibility to the public, pose a hazard including, but not limited to, unused and broken equipment, abandoned wells, shafts, or basements, hazardous or unprotected pools, ponds, or excavations, structurally unsound fences or structures, machinery which is inadequately secured or protected, lumber, trash, fences or debris that may pose a hazard to the public, storage of chemicals, gas, oil, or toxic or flammable liquids. Junk means and includes the storage of all old appliances, equipment or parts thereof, all old iron or other scrap metal, all inoperable vehicles or parts thereof, including tires, all vehicle hulks, cardboard, all lumber, old wood and mattresses, which items are not being used for their intended purpose. The term "junk" does not include orderly stacked firewood. Litter means and includes all waste material, including, but not limited to, disposable packages or containers thrown or deposited on public or private property, including the depositing of handbills on public property or cars, but not including the waste of the primary process of mining, logging, sawmilling, farming or manufacturing. Premises means any building, lot, parcel, real estate, land or portion of land, whether improved or unimproved, including adjacent sidewalks and parking strips. Refuse means vegetable offal, animal offal, discarded food, cans, bottles, waste paper, large tree limbs and all other waste substances from private and public establishments and from residences. The term "refuse" does not include small amounts of weeds, twigs, grass or other material resulting from the normal tending of lawns and gardens. Responsible person means any agent, lessee, owner or other person occupying or having charge or control of any premises. Rubbish means and includes combustible and noncombustible waste materials, except garbage; the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke, and other combustible material; paper, rags, cartons, boxes, wood, excelsior, rubber, leather, tree branches, yard trimmings, hay, straw, tin cans, metal, mineral matter, glass, crockery, and dust. The term "rubbish" shall also include animal feed and the products of and residue from animal quarters. Weed, vegetable growth and horticultural growth means and includes, but is not limited to, trees, plants, shrubs, bushes, flowers, garden vegetables and grasses and further includes all growths of every kind and character, whether domestic or wild, causing the obstruction or interference or detriment prohibited by this article. (Code 1989, § 9-2-2; Ord. of 4-11-2005, § II(9-2-2); Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-2)) Sec. 24-96. - Prohibited to create or permit nuisance; penalties. It is unlawful for any responsible persons to create, permit, maintain, suffer, carry on or allow, upon their premises, any of the acts or things declared by this article to be a public nuisance. Any person creating, keeping or maintaining a nuisance, or permitting, allowing or suffering any nuisance to be maintained, who neglects or fails to abate or remove the nuisance within 24 hours next after so creating, keeping or maintaining the nuisance, or permitting, allowing or suffering the same to be maintained, shall, for each 24 hours thereafter during which the nuisance is continued, be guilty of a separate violation of maintaining a public nuisance. (Code 1989, § 9-2-5; Ord. of 4-11-2005, § II(9-2-4); Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-5)) Sec. 24-97. - Types of public nuisances. Without limitation and in addition to other nuisances prohibited under this article and under other provisions of this Code, each of the following places, conditions or things is declared to constitute a public nuisance, and whenever the code enforcement officer determines that any of these conditions exist upon any premises, the officer may require or provide for the abatement thereof pursuant to this article: (1) Overgrown and unmaintained vegetation. The growing, maintaining, permitting or allowing of any weed, undergrowth, vegetable or horticultural growth which: a. Overhangs, encroaches upon, obstructs or in any manner interferes with the full and free use by the public of any street, sidewalk or sidewalk area upon which such property so owned or occupied abuts; b. Has grown and died upon any premises owned, occupied or in control of the responsible person or persons and which constitutes the detriment to the public health, safety or welfare, including but not limited to, a fire hazard; or c. Is so overgrown upon any premises owned, occupied or in control of the responsible person or persons, as to cause the degradation of the character of the neighborhood, as determined by the code enforcement officer; (2) Conditions causing citizen complaints. The existence of any junk, litter or refuse within the city when written complaint from two or more city residents who are impacted by the present or potential effect of the condition on them or their property, has been received by the city unless such materials are kept or stored in an orderly and sightly manner and so as not to create a fire, safety, health or sanitary hazard; (3) Accumulations of junk, litter and other refuse. The depositing, leaving or throwing away of any junk, litter or refuse within the city for an unreasonable length of time beyond what is necessary for proper disposal, except at the city landfill or in covered containers or receptacles acceptable to the enforcement officer of the city; (4) Discharge of offensive substances. The causing or permitting to be discharged, placed or thrown, or the throwing into, or upon any premises or any public street or alley of any nauseous, foul or putrid liquid or substance, or any liquid or substance likely to become nauseous, foul, offensive or putrid; (5) Generation of offensive odors or other annoyances. The erection, continuance or use of any building, room, property or other place in the city for the exercise of any trade, employment or manufacturing which results in offensive odors or other annoyances being released, and which annoys, injures or is offensive or detrimental to the health of the individuals there employed or residing, or to the public; (6) Burning causing smoke, ashes, soot or gases. The burning of refuse or other material in such a manner as to cause or permit the smoke, ashes, soot or gases arising from such burning to become discomforting or annoying, or to injure or endanger the health of any person or neighborhood; (7) Disorderly houses. The maintenance or use of any building, house, room or other structure or vehicle for the purpose of lewdness, assignation or prostitution; (8) Right-of-way obstructions and excavations. a. The presence of debris or other material on sidewalks or the public right-of-way which impedes safe passage or otherwise creates a hazardous condition; b. Any pit, basin, hole, well or other excavation which is unguarded and dangerous to life, or has been abandoned, or is no longer used for the purpose for which it was constructed, or is maintained contrary to law and all obstructions to streets, rights-of-way or other public ways in the city; c. All excavations in or under the same, which are by ordinance prohibited, or which may be made without lawful permission, or which, having been made by lawful permission, are kept and maintained after the purpose thereof has been accomplished, or for an unreasonable length of time; (9) Alcoholic beverage establishments operated contrary to law. All premises, buildings and vehicles whereon or wherein intoxicating liquor is manufactured, sold, bargained, exchanged, given away, furnished, disposed of, consumed or permitted to be consumed, in violation of laws of the state and ordinances of the city; (10) Unsecured vacant buildings. All vacant, unused or unoccupied buildings and structures within the city, which are allowed to become or remain open to entrance by unauthorized persons or the general public, because of broken, missing or open doors, windows or other openings, so that the same may be used by vagrants or other persons in a manner detrimental to the health and welfare of the inhabitants of the city; (11) Blighted buildings. All buildings, dwellings, or property on which one or more of the conditions exist such that the building, dwelling or property is blighted as such term is defined in this article; (12) Discarded or abandoned appliances or other locking containers. Any refrigerator, ice box or deep freeze locker having a capacity of 1½ cubic feet or more or any other container manufactured, custom-made or homemade designed for storage which is discarded, abandoned or left in any place accessible to children and which has not had the door latching mechanism removed to prevent the latching or locking of the door; (13) Signs and other advertising on public property or rights-of-ways. Any sign, poster or other advertising matter of any nature placed upon a telephone, utility or other poles, trees, sidewalks, streets, signs, traffic signs or other traffic control devices or other structures or places within streets, alleys or other public places or rights-of-way; (14) Gambling structures or other areas and gambling devices. All buildings or parts thereof, vehicles, or other structures, wherein any gambling may be found, and any gambling device may be found, except as licensed and within the scope of the requirement of the license required under state law and this Code; (15) Water runoff. The depositing or allowing of irrigation or other water to run by any street, alley or other public place, in such manner as to cause settling or damage to the street, alley or other public place, or to cause annoyance, damage or hazard to any user of the street, alley or other public place; (16) Nuisance animals. Animals constituting a nuisance as provided in chapter 6; (17) Noise. The making of noise prohibited by this article. (Code 1989, § 9-2-3; Ord. of 4-11-2005, § II(9-2-3); Ord. of 9-8-2008, § II(9-2-3)) Secs. 24-98—24-122. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - NOISE
Sec. 24-123. - Unreasonable loud noise prohibited. The creating of any unreasonably loud, disturbing and unnecessary noise within the limits of the city is prohibited. Noise of such character, intensity or duration as to be detrimental to the life or health of any individual, or in disturbance of the public peace and welfare, is prohibited. (Code 1989, § 9-1-4(a)) Sec. 24-124. - Types of prohibited noise. The following acts, among others and without limitation, are declared to be loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises in violation of this division: (1) Horns.
