The sign shall be clearly visible from a public street. It shall be erected not less than 15 days before the official public hearing date. (f) The building inspector or his representative will inform the applicant of the public hearing dates. (g) The planning and zoning commission shall prepare and submit the necessary minutes, evaluations, and recommendations to the city council prior to the city council's scheduled public hearing. If the planning and zoning commission fails to submit a recommendation prior to the city council public hearing, the city council may proceed with the presumption of approval from the planning and zoning commission. (h) The city council, at its public hearing, will review and consider the evaluations and recommendations from the planning and zoning commission and may choose to adopt or reject or modify the planning commission recommendations, or the business may be tabled for additional study, but the action must include a specific meeting date for reconsideration. (i) Final action must be taken by the city council in the form of an official chapter amendment as specified by the city Charter. (j) So that the purpose of this zoning chapter will be served and so that health, public safety and general welfare will be secured, the city council may in its legislative discretion approve or deny the proposed amendment as submitted, reduce the land area for which the application is made, change the zoning district to one other than that requested, or add or delete zoning conditions as the council deems appropriate. The city council shall also have the legislative discretion to grant a conditional use in its decision to rezone property. An action to defer a decision on the proposed amendment shall include a specific meeting date to which the proposed amendment is deferred. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 12.04) Sec. 40-149. - Referral to planning commission. All proposed zoning amendments before adoption shall be referred to the planning and zoning commission at least 30 days prior to the required city council public hearing for its recommendation and report which shall not be binding. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 12.05) Sec. 40-150. - Procedures for the call and conduct of zoning public hearings. In order to conform to O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq., the following policies and procedures shall govern the call and conduct of all zoning public hearings in the city: (1) All required zoning hearings shall be properly advertised and have proper notice according to state law and the zoning chapter of the city. (2) All such hearings shall be open to the general public, and no person shall be excluded for any reason other than grossly disruptive or offensive actions. (3) The purpose of holding a zoning public hearing is to listen to the views of the citizens of the community, and then evaluate the entire matter at a later time or official meeting. No cross examination or prolonged argumentative questioning of the hearing body shall be permitted. Decorum and order shall prevail. (4) Before any requests for amendments or zoning changes may be considered, the city clerk shall verify and announce publicly for the record that: a. All necessary submission requirements as established in the zoning chapter have been met. b. All requirements under state law for advertising and posting of a sign on the property for rezoning, if appropriate, including any time limitations, have been met. (5) The chairperson shall announce publicly the convening of the hearing on each amendment or change, identifying specifically, if appropriate, the property proposed for zoning and stating the present zoning classification and the proposed zoning classifications. (6) Any citizen and all parties in interest shall be given opportunity to be heard, provided that oral presentations for each side of the issue shall be limited to 30 minutes, and those persons wishing to make oral presentations have signed a hearing register with their name, address and affiliation or standing, and indicated which side of the issue they wish to address. The chairperson shall have the authority to place more specific time limits on individual oral presenters (as a class), so long as each side is given its full amount of allotted time, or to extend the allotted time of the public hearing to one hour for each side, if warranted. (7) Submission of written comments and supporting data shall be allowed, in addition to or as supplement to oral presentations, without affecting time limits on oral presentation. To be accepted and entered into the record, these comments must be clearly identified as to the issue concerned, and carry the name, address, and affiliation of the respondent. The receipt and acceptance of written comments shall be read into the record of the chairperson or the chairperson's designee. (8) Those persons wishing to make oral or written presentations before the hearing body should be aware that the hearing body is attempting to make an objective decision, based on the adopted standards for zoning decisions of the city and is interested only in factual presentations and information which can be supported and which is accurately and carefully presented. The chairperson may declare out of order any presenter making emotional arguments or extraneous statements not germane to the issue. Only presentation and information relevant to issues raised in the city's adopted standards for zoning decisions shall be considered germane. (9) Only members of the hearing body may question a person making a presentation during the hearing. In order for a person in attendance to speak, the chairperson must first recognize that person. (10) The order of procedure for each hearing shall be as outlined below: a. After convening and identifying the public hearing, the chairperson will request the register for that hearing and briefly recite the procedures in effect, including any specific time limits. b. Presentations, if desired, by the proponents of the proposed zoning change or amendment. c. Questions by members of the hearing body of the proponents. d. Presentations, if desired, by the opponents of the proposed zoning change or amendment. e. Questions by members of the hearing body of the opponents. f. Upon conclusion of the presentations and questions, the chairperson will thank all for their interest and attendance, ensure that all views and the entire matter will be given careful consideration, and shall close that hearing. (11) The chairperson will then announce the time and place of the meeting of the mayor and city council which will have the proposed change on the agenda for official action. (12) Any other scheduled public hearing or amendment or change shall then be convened, utilizing the same procedures. (13) Only normal minutes shall be maintained by any zoning public hearing as a matter of course. However, upon receipt of written request from an affected party or parties at least one week prior to the scheduled public hearing, the city shall have a transcript prepared, provided that the entire cost of preparation shall be borne by the affected party or parties making such request. Agreement to this by the party or parties making such request must be provided to the city in writing before preparations for such a transcript will be undertaken. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 12.06) Sec. 40-151. - Standards for zoning decisions. In order to conform to the O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq., the following standards will be considered as appropriate and as relevant to a particular zoning decision by the city council when adopting, changing, or amending the zoning chapter or the zoning map: (1) Ensure that the proposed change is reasonable and consistent with the spirit, purpose, and intent of the zoning chapter. (2) Consider the changes in community characteristics which may take place because of the proposed change, and consider the consistency with and effect of the change on current public growth and development policies and plans. (3) Consider the relative effectiveness or ineffectiveness of the present wording or distracting of this chapter, and whether a justification for change exists because of special reasons or a change in conditions. (4) Consider the effect upon the public interest of granting or denying the proposed change, and determine that the change will serve the best interests of the city, as compared to any hardship imposed upon the individual property owner. (5) Consider the existing land use pattern, and specifically the presence or absence in the adjacent surrounding area of conditions and uses which are the same or similar in character to any proposed change or use, and the possible creation of an isolated district unrelated to adjacent districts. (6) Determine that the proposed change will not substantially injure or detract from the use or value of neighboring property, or from the general character of adjacent and nearby property in the surrounding area. (7) Consider the unique characteristics of the property involved, and whether the property to be affected by the zoning proposal has some reasonable economic use as currently zoned or whether there are substantial reasons why the property cannot be used in accordance with existing zoning. (8) Consider the effect of the proposed change upon the logical, efficient, and economical extensions of public services and facilities, or possible overtaxing or burdening of existing public services or facilities, including but not limited to utilities, streets, schools, and public safety services, and also the associated costs to the local government in providing, improving, increasing, or maintaining such facilities and services. (9) Consider the impact of the change with respect to probable effects upon highway traffic and safety, and especially access near intersections. (10) Consider the impact of the proposed change upon the environment, including but not limited to drainage, soil erosion and sedimentation, flooding, noise, air quality, and water quality and quantity. (11) Determine that the zoning proposal will permit suitable use or uses in view of the subject property/physical characteristics, the use and development of adjacent and nearby properties, existing zoning patterns, existing or proposed public facilities or services, environmental impacts, and current public growth and development policies and plans of the city. (12) Consider whether the change is designed to correct an improper situation, or would merely result in the granting of special privileges not available to adjacent or surrounding properties. (13) Consider the conformity of the proposed change with the city's adopted comprehensive plan. (14) Consider any other factors relevant to balancing the city's interests in promoting and protecting the public health, safety, morality, or general welfare against a right to unrestricted use of property. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 12.07) Sec. 40-152. - Disclosure of financial interests by city officials. (a) Members of the planning and zoning commissionand city council are required to disclose any financial interest or property interest affecting property which is subject of a rezoning action in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 21-5-1 et seq. (b) The term "financial interest" means an interest in the ownership of a business entity of ten percent or more by a planning and zoning commission member or city councilmember or by a member of his immediate family. (c) The term "property interest" means a direct ownership of real property, regardless of the percentage of ownership, by a planning and zoning commission memberor city councilmember or a member of his immediate family. (d) The term "rezoning action" means an action to adopt an amendment to a zoning chapter which rezones property from one zoning classification to another. (e) A planning and zoning commission member or city councilmember who has a property or financial interest shall disclose the nature and extent of that interest in writing to the mayor and city council. (f) A planning and zoning commission member or city councilmember with a property or financial interest in property to be rezoned shall disqualify himself from voting and shall not take any action to influence the application for rezoning. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 12.08) Sec. 40-153. - Disclosure of campaign contributions. Applicants for rezoning or their authorized attorney or other representative and opponents to any rezoning action who have made aggregate campaign contributions of $250.00 or more to a local governmental official involved with zoning actions for the city shall file written disclosure statements with the city in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 21-5-1 et seq. (1) Applicant or attorney for applicant. a. Any applicant or attorney or other person representing an applicant for rezoning who has made an aggregate contribution of $250.00 or more to a government official within two years shall file a disclosure statement with the city clerk. b. The disclosure statement shall show the name and position of the government official to whom the contributions were made and include the amount of each contribution made within two years preceding the filing of the application for rezoning. c. The disclosure statement shall be filed with the city clerk within ten days of filing the application for rezoning. (2) Opponents to rezoning. a. An opponent to a rezoning action who made campaign contributions which aggregate $250.00 or more to a government official within two years of the filing of the rezoning application shall file a disclosure statement with the mayor and city council. b. The term "opponent" means anyone who, on behalf of himself or someone else, discusses or contacts, either orally or in writing, a government official in opposition to a rezoning application or who speaks at a hearing in opposition to a rezoning application. c. The opponents' disclosure statement shall show the name of the government official to whom contributions were made and the amount or description of each contribution made within two years of the filing of the application for rezoning. d. The disclosure statement shall be filed at least five days before the first hearing on the rezoning application. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 12.09) Sec. 40-154. - Limits upon reconsideration of rezoning petitions. In the event the mayor and council hold a hearing as herein prescribed for the consideration of a zoning decision which is for the rezoning of property and the amendment to the zoning chapter to accomplish the rezoning is defeated by the mayor and council, then the same property may not again be considered for rezoning until the expiration of at least six months immediately following the defeat of the rezoning by the mayor and council. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 12.10) Secs. 40-155—40-176. - Reserved. DIVISION 6. - VARIANCE PROCEDURES
Sec. 40-177. - Planning and zoning commission to hear and decide; notice of procedural requirements. The planning and zoning commission shall hear and decide upon all variances to the city's zoning chapter. All variances will follow the same public notice and procedural requirements as in a rezoning request by a property owner. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 14.00) Sec. 40-178. - Request for a variance. The planning and zoning commission may authorize in specific cases such variance from the terms of these regulations as will not be contrary to the public interest where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of these regulations will, in an individual case, result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship, so that the spirit of these regulations shall be observed, public safety and welfare secured and substantial justice done; provided, however, that a variance shall not be granted for use of land or building or structure that is prohibited by this chapter in the district in question. Such variance may be granted in an individual case upon a finding by the planning and zoning commission that the following exists: (1) There are extraordinary and exceptional conditions pertaining to the particular piece of property in question because of its size, shape or topography; (2) The application of these regulations to this particular piece of property would create a practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship; (3) Such conditions are peculiar to the particular piece of property involved; (4) Relief, if granted, would not cause substantial detriment to the public good or impair the purpose and intent of these regulations, provided, however, that no variance may be granted for a use of land or building or structure that is prohibited by this chapter; (5) A literal interpretation of this chapter would deprive the applicant of any rights that others in the same district are allowed; and (6) Provided that the planning and zoning commission imposes or requires such additional restrictions and standards as may be necessary to protect the health and safety of workers and residents in the community, and to protect the value and use of property in the general neighborhood; and provided, that wherever the planning and zoning commission shall find, in the case of any permit granted pursuant to the provisions of these regulations that any of the terms, conditions or restrictions upon which such permit was granted are not being complied with, the planning and zoning commission shall rescind and revoke such permit after giving due notice to all parties concerned and granting full opportunity for a public hearing. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 14.01) Sec. 40-179. - Forms. Applications for variances shall be made on forms provided by the building inspector and all information required on the forms shall be provided by the appellant. Forms shall be filed with the city clerk and the appellant shall pay the city for expenses incidental to the variance. No form shall be accepted by the city unless it contains all pertinent information and is accompanied by the appropriate fee payable to the city, to defray expenses. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 14.02) Secs. 40-180—40-196. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - NONCONFORMING USES
Sec. 40-197. - Declaration of intent. It is the intent of this article that any lawful use of the land or buildings existing at the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, or at the date of any subsequent amendment thereto, which would be made no longer permissible as a new use, or otherwise would be in violation under the terms of this article, is hereby declared to be a nonconforming use. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 6.00) Sec. 40-198. - Continuation of uses. Nonconforming uses may be continued as long as they remain otherwise lawful, subject to the following provisions and provided that: (1) A nonconforming use shall not be changed to another nonconforming use. (2) A nonconforming use may not be extended, enlarged, or altered in a way which increases its nonconformity. (3) A nonconforming use may not be re-established after discontinuance for one year. (4) Once changed to a conforming use, no land or building shall be permitted to revert to a nonconforming use. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 6.01) Sec. 40-199. - Change of use. A nonconforming building or use shall be considered as such unless and until it complies with the regulations of the district in which it is located. When a building or use is changed to fully comply with all provisions of this chapter, it shall then be considered a conforming use and shall not revert to a nonconforming use except in conformity with provisions of this chapter, such as a lawfully granted variance. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 6.02) Sec. 40-200. - Building damaged by fire, explosion, accident, or calamity. A nonconforming building which has been damaged or destroyed by fire, explosion, accident or calamity (as contrasted to deterioration due to time or neglect) may not be rebuilt, altered or repaired after damage exceeding 50 percent of its replacement cost at the time of destruction except in conformity with this chapter. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 6.03) Sec. 40-201. - Building condemned. A nonconforming building which has been legally condemned shall not be rebuilt or used except in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 6.04) Sec. 40-202. - Discontinuance or abandonment. Any nonconforming use of land or building, when discontinued, abandoned, or vacated for any reason may be resumed at any time within one year as a similar nonconforming use. After a period of vacancy or abandonment of one year without resumption, any use thereafter shall conform to the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 6.05) Sec. 40-203. - Change of tenancy or ownership. There may be a change in tenancy, ownership, or management of an existing nonconforming use, provided that all other applicable laws and regulations are complied with, there is no change in the nature or character of such nonconforming use, and there has not been a period of discontinuance or abandonment exceeding one year. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 6.06) Sec. 40-204. - Ordinary maintenance and repair. Nothing in these provisions is intended to preclude ordinary repairs and maintenance by an owner, or those ordered as necessary to protect the public health, safety, or welfare. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 6.07) Sec. 40-205. - Temporary use. A temporary nonconforming use, which will benefit the public health or welfare or promote proper development of a district in conformity with the intent of this chapter, may be permitted for a period of not more than one month, on the approval of the city council. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 6.08) Sec. 40-206. - Nonconforming signs. Any sign existing at the time of the passing of this chapter that does not conform in use, location, height or size with the regulations of the district in which it is located, shall be considered a nonconforming use and may continue in such use in its present location for a period of five years from the date of the passage the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, but not after. The continuation of such nonconforming use after the expiration of five years shall be a violation of this chapter. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 6.09) Secs. 40-207—40-235. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - CONDITIONAL AND TEMPORARY USES
Sec. 40-236. - Initiation of conditional use. (a) Conditional uses as listed in any particular zoning district are declared to possess characteristics which require certain controls in order to ensure compatibility with other uses in the district within which they are proposed for location. (b) A conditional use subject to approval of the city council in a particular zone may be initiated by the owner of the property proposed for the conditional use by filing an application with the planning and zoning commission and paying the appropriate fee. Reapplication for a conditional use may not be heard for six months from the date of the prior decision of the mayor and city council. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 13.00) Sec. 40-237. - Application for conditional uses. Applications for conditional uses shall be obtained from the planning and zoning commission. The applications shall include forms designated by the city, application information and requirements as outlined in this chapter, any other supporting documentation as required by the building inspector, and fees as designated by the city. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 13.01) Sec. 40-238. - Procedure for review of conditional uses. Upon receipt of a complete application for a conditional use as authorized in this chapter, the planning and zoning commission shall hear and decide upon the application. All applications for conditional use will follow the same public notice and procedural requirements as in a rezoning request by a property owner outlined in section 40-148. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 13.02) Sec. 40-239. - Standards for granting/denying conditional uses. The planning and zoning commission and city council shall use the standards for zoning decisions as outlined in section 40-151, as appropriate, in determining whether to recommend, grant, or deny, as the case may be, a requested conditional use. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 13.03) Sec. 40-240. - General permit requirements. Conditional uses shall be permitted subject only to a determination by the building inspector that they conform to all conditions set both by this chapter for the district in which they are located and by the city council for the particular development proposed. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 13.04) Sec. 40-241. - Temporary use for zoning compliance. (a) The building inspector is authorized to issue a temporary certificate of zoning compliance for temporary uses, as follows: (1) Carnival, circus, or fair, for a period not to exceed 21 days, subject to the approval of the city council in the C-1, C-2, and C-3 districts. (2) Religious meeting in a tent or other temporary structure in C-2 and C-3 districts, for a period not to exceed 60 days. (3) Open lot sale of Christmas trees, fruit and vegetables, and other harvested products in the C1, C-2, C-3, and I districts for a period not to exceed 45 days. (4) Contractor's office and equipment sheds, in any district, for a period of one year, provided that such office is placed on the property to which it is appurtenant. (b) All temporary certificates of zoning compliance may be renewed, provided that it is determined that the use is clearly of a temporary nature, will cause no increased traffic congestion, and will not create a nuisance to surrounding uses. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 13.05) Secs. 40-242—40-260. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 40-261. - Official zoning map. (a) The location and boundaries of the city's zoning districts are shown on the map that is designated as the official zoning map of the city. The map is hereby made a part of this chapter and shall be available for public inspection at the city hall together with applicable amendments. All notations, references, and other information shown on this official zoning map are a part of this chapter and have the same force and effect as if the zoning map and all such notations, references and other information shown were fully set forth or described herein. As evidence of its authenticity, the official zoning map and amendments shall be attested and certified by the clerk of the city with signature and the city seal impressed thereon. (b) No changes of any nature shall be made on the official zoning map or matter shown thereon except in conformity with the procedures for amendment set forth in this chapter. Any unauthorized change of any kind by any person or persons shall be considered a violation of this chapter and is punishable as provided by law. (c) Regardless of the existence of purported copies of the official zoning map which may from time to time be made or published, the official zoning map located in city hall and certified by the city clerk shall be the final authority as to the current zoning status of land in the city. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 3.01) Sec. 40-262. - Interpretation of district boundaries. The boundaries between districts are, unless otherwise indicated, either the centerlines of streets, lanes, watercourses, rights-of-way of power lines and other public utilities or such lines extended or lines parallel thereto. Where the boundaries of a single district are indicated as including directly opposite sides of a street, lane, lake, or watercourse, or right-of-way of a power line of other public utility, for any portion of its length, the district so indicated shall be construed to apply to the entire bed of such street, lane, lake or watercourse, or right-of-way of such power line, railroad or other public utility, lying within such portion of its length. Where uncertainty exists as to the location of any the boundaries as shown on the zoning map, the following rules shall apply: (1) Where a district boundary is indicated approximately following the centerline of a street, lane, lake or watercourse, or right-of-way of a power line or other public utility, such centerline shall be construed to be such boundary. (2) Where a district boundary is indicated as approximately following a lot line or other property line, such lot line or other property line shall be construed to be such boundary. (3) Where a district boundary divides a lot or runs through undivided property, the location of such boundary, unless otherwise specified by figures on the zoning map, shall be determined by the use of the scale appearing on the map. (4) Where district boundaries are indicated as approximately following the corporate limits of the city, such corporate limits shall be construed to be such boundaries. (5) Where district boundaries are indicated as approximately parallel to the centerline of streets or highways, such district boundaries shall be construed as being parallel and at such distance therefrom as indicated on the zoning map. If no distance or indication is given on the zoning map, such dimensions shall be determined by the use of the scale as shown on the zoning map. (6) Where a district boundary line divides a lot which is a single ownership lot at the time of the enactment of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, the use classification of the larger portion may be extended to the remainder without recourse to amendment procedure except that such extension shall not include any part of a lot that lies more than 25 feet beyond the district boundary line. (7) In case any further uncertainty exists after applying the above rules, the city council shall interpret the intent of the zoning map and determine the location of such. (8) Where a public road, street, alley, or other right-of-way is officially vacated or abandoned, the regulations applicable to the property to which it is reverted shall apply to such vacated or abandoned road, street, alley or right-of-way. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 3.02) Sec. 40-263. - Annexation; deannexation. In the event of changes in the city limits removing territory from the city, district boundaries shall be construed as moving with the city limits. In the event of annexation of new areas to the city, such areas shall be considered to be in the R-40 district until otherwise classified. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 15.04) Sec. 40-264. - Regulations are minimum. The regulations set by this chapter within each district shall be the minimum requirements, and shall apply uniformly to each class or kind of structure or land, except as hereinafter provided. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 4.00) Sec. 40-265. - Use of land, buildings, and structures. No building or structure or land within the corporate limits shall hereafter be used or occupied, and no building or structure or part thereof shall be erected, constructed, reconstructed, located, moved, subdivided, or altered except in conformity with the regulations herein specified for the district in which it is located. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 4.01) Sec. 40-266. - Permitted density. (a) No building or structure shall hereafter be erected, located, constructed, or altered to: (1) House a greater number of families or occupy a smaller lot area per family. (2) Have narrower or smaller front, rear, or side yards, or other open spaces than are herein required, or in any other manner contrary to the provisions and intent of this chapter. (3) Occupy a greater percentage of the area of the lot than required. (b) No part of a yard, or other open space, or off-street parking or loading required about or in connection with any building for the purpose of complying with this chapter shall be included as part of a yard, open space, or off-street parking or loading space similarly required for any other building. (c) Right-of-way easements for streets and roads shall not be considered a part of a lot or open space, or front, rear, or side yard for the purpose of meeting yard requirements. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 4.02) Sec. 40-267. - Lot reduction prohibited. No yard or lot existing at the time of the passage of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, including those substandard lots of record which are adjacent lots in the same ownership at the time of the passage of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, shall be sold or otherwise reduced in dimension or area below the minimum requirements set forth herein. Yards or lots created after the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall meet at least the minimum requirements established by this chapter. This section shall not apply when a portion of a lot is acquired for public use. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 4.03) Sec. 40-268. - Use of substandard lots of record. Where the owner of a lot at the time of the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived does not own sufficient land to enable him to conform to the dimensional requirements of this chapter, such lot may nonetheless be used as a building site, provided that the lot requirements are not reduced below the minimum specified in this chapter by more than 20 percent. If, however, the owner of two or more adjoining lots with insufficient land dimensions, decides to build on or sell off these lots, he must first combine the lots to comply with the dimensional requirements of this chapter. Any lot requiring dimensional waivers below the 20 percent minimum set forth in this section may be approved by the planning and zoning commission and city council upon application and process as a variance, provided that further decreased dimensional requirements shall conform as closely as possible to the required dimensions. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 4.04) Sec. 40-269. - One principal building on a lot. Except for group developments, only one principal building and its permitted customary accessory buildings may hereafter be erected or located on any one lot. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 4.05) Sec. 40-270. - Public street frontage. No building shall be erected or located on a lot which does not abut at least 25 feet on a public street. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 4.06) Sec. 40-271. - Permitted height. No building or structure shall be erected, converted, enlarged, reconstructed or structurally altered to exceed the height limit regulations of the district in which the building is located, except that those height limits shall not apply to structures not intended for human occupancy and clearly incidental to the main use of the principal building, such as church spires, flag poles, chimneys, monuments, individual domestic radio and television antennas, water towers, or similar structures. Height limits shall apply to signs of all types. The erection of commercial radio, television, wireless, relay, or other types of antenna towers, where permitted, shall abide by the regulations set forth therein. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 4.07) Sec. 40-272. - Public street access. Access to public streets shall be maintained in accordance with the following requirements: (1) Each principal use shall be located on a lot or parcel which provides frontage on a public street having a right-of-way of not less than 30 feet. (2) All dwellings on a lot shall have access to a public street by means of a passageway open to the sky at least 20 feet in width. (3) Any building established as a part of a group development project which cannot properly be served by emergency or service vehicles from an abutting street shall be made accessible to such vehicles by a paved driveway having a roadbed width of not less than 20 feet, exclusive of parking spaces. (4) Local streets which will carry less than 600 vehicles per day may have access points as needed to fit the development. Collector streets and arterial streets which are projected to carry more than 600 vehicles per day shall have a minimum distance between access points equal to seven times the speed limit for that street. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 4.08) Sec. 40-273. - Corner lots. The side yard setback requirements for corner lots shall be the same as the front yard requirements for adjoining lots on the same street. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 4.09) Sec. 40-274. - Double frontage lots. On lots having frontage on two streets, but not located on a corner, the minimum front yard shall be provided on each street in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 4.10) Sec. 40-275. - Modification of front yard setback requirements. The setback requirements of this chapter shall not apply to any lot where the average setback of existing buildings on already built-upon lots located wholly or in part within 100 feet on each side of such lot and within the same block and zoning district and fronting on the same street as such lot is less than the minimum required setback. In such cases, the setback of the lot may be less than the required setback, but not less than the average of the existing setbacks on the developed lots. However, in no case shall setbacks be less than 15 feet from the street right-of-way upon which the lot fronts. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 4.11) Sec. 40-276. - Vision clearance at corners, curb cuts, and railroad crossings. In all districts no fence, wall, shrubbery or other obstruction to vision between the heights of 2½ feet and ten feet above the finished grade of streets shall be erected, permitted, or maintained within 20 feet of the intersection of the right-of-way lines of streets or of streets and railroads. Notwithstanding any part of this chapter or any permit granted or any variance granted by the planning and zoning commission, no type of structure, vehicle, tree, plant, vegetation, sign or fence, or any type of obstacle or any portion thereof shall be placed or retained in such a manner which would create a traffic hazard or would obstruct the vision clearance of corners, curb cuts, or railroad crossings in any zone. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 4.12) Sec. 40-277. - Illumination not to be a nuisance. Illumination devices, such as, but not limited to flood or spotlights, shall be so placed and so shielded as to prevent the rays of illumination therefrom being cast into neighboring dwellings and approaching vehicles. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 4.13) Sec. 40-278. - Unsightly or unsanitary storage. No rubbish, salvage materials, junk, or miscellaneous refuse shall be openly stored or kept in the open and no weeds shall be allowed to go uncut within any zones when the same may be construed to be a menace to public health and safety by the appropriate health department, or to have a depressing influence upon property values in the area. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 4.14) Sec. 40-279. - Planted buffer strips. Where commercial or industrial districts abut residential districts, a ten-foot-wide buffer strip shall be provided along the abutting property lines, and the ten feet shall be added to the side or rear yard requirements as well as the lot width unless specified otherwise in this chapter. Such buffer strip shall be planted with evergreen trees or shrubs that grow at least eight feet tall and provide an effective visual screen. Such plantings must be in accordance with all provisions of this chapter, and shall be maintained in a healthy, growing condition. Fences or walls may also be required. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 4.15) Sec. 40-280. - Code requirements and state and federal regulations. All developments, structures, and uses shall meet the requirements of all federal and state regulations in effect, including, but not limited to, state department of transportation and state fire marshal regulations, state uniform construction codes, state department of human resource public health regulations, and state environmental protection division environmental rules and regulations. Approval of a building or occupancy permit by the local government does not constitute a certification of compliance with such codes or regulations, and does not abrogate responsibility of the owner to so comply. Where such codes exceed the minimum requirements of this chapter, the stricter provisions shall apply. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 4.16) Secs. 40-281—40-308. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - OFF-STREET PARKING AND LOADING REQUIREMENTS
Sec. 40-309. - Required. Areas suitable to provide off-street parking, loading, and service areas out of public rights-of-way shall hereafter be required in all districts at the time of the initial construction of any principal building; or when a structural alteration or other change in a building produces an increase in dwelling units, guest rooms, floor area, seating or bed capacity; or when a conversion in use occurs. Such off-street parking, loading, and service areas shall have direct access to a public road or street, and shall be provided and maintained in accordance with the requirements and provisions of this division. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 7.00) Sec. 40-310. - Parking spaces may not be reduced. Off-street parking spaces shall not be reduced below the minimum required number for the use of facility to which they are assigned. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 7.01) Sec. 40-311. - Drainage, construction and maintenance. All off-street parking, loading and service areas shall be constructed of concrete, asphalt or gravel with appropriate stormwater drainage. All such areas shall be at all times maintained at the expense of the owners thereof, in a clean, orderly and dust-free condition. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 7.02) Sec. 40-312. - Separation from walkways, sidewalks and streets. All off-street parking, loading and service areas shall be separated from walkways, sidewalks and streets by curbing or other suitable protective device. Curbing and other protection devices must be set back a minimum of three feet to prevent vehicle overhang. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 7.03) Sec. 40-313. - Parking area design. Parking stalls shall have a minimum width of nine feet and length of 18 feet. There shall be provided adequate interior driveways to connect each parking space with a public right-of-way. Interior driveways shall be at least 24 feet wide where used with 90-degree angle parking, at least 18 feet wide where used with 60-degree angle parking, at least 13 feet wide where used with 45 degree parking, and at least 12 feet wide where used with parallel parking or where there is no parking. Interior driveways shall be at least 12 feet wide for one-way traffic movement and at least 20 feet wide for two-way traffic movement. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 7.04) Sec. 40-314. - Landscaping of parking areas. Any off-street parking facility providing 20 or more parking spaces is required to provide approved landscaping in accordance with the following requirements. Such a facility must provide a landscaping plan to the building inspector and have it approved before the issuance of a land use permit. Installation of plant materials and other requirements shall have been completed prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy. Other parking facilities are encouraged to include landscaping. (1) Any off-street parking facility of 20 cars or more shall also provide the equivalent of one parking space per each ten cars and each fraction thereof, to be planted with at least one tree with a minimum diameter (measured at the location of its greatest width) of two inches and grass or ground cover. The exact location within the parking facility is optional with each design, but the planted area herein referred to shall be in addition to perimeter buffer strips and to other landscaping on the property outside the parking facility. (2) Where healthy trees or other native plant material exists on a site prior to its development, islands and buffers of such material shall be incorporated into the parking lot design with special attention to the saving and preservation of trees with trunk caliper of four inches or more. (3) Front perimeter landscape areas. A 20-foot-wide strip of land, located between the front property line and the vehicular use area shall be landscaped. Width of sidewalks shall not be included within the 20-foot-wide front setback perimeter landscape area. (4) Side and rear perimeter landscaped areas. A six-foot-wide strip of land, located between the side and rear property lines and the vehicular use area, shall be landscaped, except that where the strip of land to be landscaped is between a side or rear property line and a vehicular use area used as an accessory, a four-foot-wide strip of land shall be landscaped. (5) Material requirements in perimeter area. a. Tree count. The total tree count requirements within the front setback perimeter landscape area shall be determined by using a ratio of one tree for each 25 linear feet of lot frontage or major portion thereof with 50 percent of the trees being shade trees. b. Ground cover. Grass or other ground cover shall be placed on all areas within the front, side and rear setback perimeter landscape areas not occupied by other landscape material, or permitted accessways. (6) Any required landscaping shall be maintained by the owner in a living, growing, and well-kept manner, and shall be replaced as necessary to conform to these provisions. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 7.05) Sec. 40-315. - Parking lot ingress and egress. For any off-street parking facility providing five or more spaces, curb cuts not wider than 24 feet for entrances into or exits from parking lots shall be no closer than 100 feet apart, measured from centerline to centerline, unless special circumstances make it impractical. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 7.06) Sec. 40-316. - Joint parking facilities. Two or more neighboring uses of the same or different types may provide joint facilities, provided the number of off-street parking spaces is not less than the sum of the individual requirements. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 7.07) Sec. 40-317. - Pavement markings and signs. Each off-street parking space shall be clearly marked, and pavement directional arrows or signs shall be provided in each travel way wherever necessary. Markers, directional arrows and signs shall be properly maintained so as to ensure their maximum efficiency. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 7.08) Sec. 40-318. - Location of parking space for land uses. The off-street parking facilities required for all uses shall be located on the lot or within 400 feet of the permitted use requiring such off-street parking, such distance to be measured along lines of public access to the property between the nearest point of the parking facility to the building to be served. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 7.09) Sec. 40-319. - Number of parking spaces. (a) In order to ensure a proper and uniform development of public parking areas throughout the area of jurisdiction of this chapter, to relieve traffic congestion on the streets and to minimize any detrimental effects on adjacent properties, off-street parking space shall be provided and maintained as called for in the following schedule. For any use or class of use not mentioned in this schedule, the requirements shall be the same as a similar use as mentioned herein. Parking requirements for additions to existing uses shall be based only upon the new addition even if the existing use is deficient. (b) Required parking spaces shall be maintained and shall not be encroached upon so long as the main building or structure remains, unless an equivalent number of such spaces are provided elsewhere in conformance with this chapter. The owner of a building, structure or other land use requiring off-street parking spaces must show, to the satisfaction of the building inspector, that he is the record title holder of the property proposed for off-street parking uses, or that he is the lessee of such property.
(Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 7.10) Sec. 40-320. - Off-street loading requirements. (a) On the same premises with every building, structure or part thereof, erected and occupied for manufacturing, storage, warehouse, truck freight terminal, goods display, department store, wholesale store, market, hotel, hospital, mortuary, laundry, dry cleaning or other uses similarly involving the receipt or distribution of vehicles, materials or merchandise, there shall be provided and maintained on the lot adequate space for standing, loading and unloading services in order to avoid undue interference with public use of the streets and alleys. (b) Such loading and unloading space, unless otherwise adequately provided for, shall be an area ten feet by 50 feet, with 15-foot height clearance and shall be provided according to the following schedule:
(Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 7.11) Sec. 40-321. - Minimum number of loading spaces required. Industrial, wholesale and retail operations shall provide space as follows: (1) Off-street loading spaces shall be provided as appropriate to the functions and scope of the operation of individual or groups of buildings and uses. (2) Off-street loading spaces shall be designed and constructed so that all maneuvering to park and unpark occurs within the property lines of the premises. Loading spaces shall be provided so as not to interfere with the free, normal movement of vehicles and pedestrians on public rights-of-way. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 7.12) Secs. 40-322—40-345. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - SIGNS
Sec. 40-346. - Permit required. All signs within the city shall be erected, constructed and maintained in accordance with the provisions below, and shall require a sign permit to be issued unless specifically exempted in section 40-351. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 8.00) Sec. 40-347. - Construction and maintenance. All signs must be constructed of durable materials, in a structurally safe manner, be maintained in good condition and appearance, be compatible in appearance and aesthetics to other signs in the general area, and must not be allowed to become deteriorated or dilapidated. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 8.01) Sec. 40-348. - Prohibited signs. The following types of signs are prohibited in the city: (1) Off-site or off-premises business signs. (2) Portable signs. (3) Signs with beacons, animated and running lights or other flashing lights. (4) Signs placed on trees, rocks, or utility poles. (5) Air- and gas-filled devices, except as an authorized temporary or special event sign. (6) Strings of light not permanently mounted to a rigid background, except holiday decorations with no commercial messages. (7) Fluttering ribbons, banners, pennants or streamers. (8) No sign shall be constructed, erected or maintained that uses the words, "Stop," "Emergency" or "Danger," or uses emergency colors of red, blue or amber, in such a manner as to imply danger or emergency, or which is a copy or imitation of an official traffic control sign. (9) Roof signs, except on the facings of roofs when no other space is available for the mounting of signs. Supports for roof signs shall be attached to the structural supports of the roof, and shall not project above the ridge line of the roof. (10) Illuminated signs from which direct rays of light are projected onto a lot other than on the lot where the illumination occurs. (11) Signs which move or have any moving or animated parts, or which emit or utilize in any manner any sound capable of being heard with normal hearing. (12) Billboards. (13) Signs which advertise an activity that is illegal under state or federal law or regulations in effect at the location of such signs or activity. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 8.02) Sec. 40-349. - No signs shall hamper traffic safety. No sign shall be erected or continued that obstructs the sight distance along a public right-of-way, would tend by its location, color or nature, to be confused with or obstruct the view of traffic signs or signals, or to be confused with a flashing light of an emergency vehicle, would by its nature tend to confuse motorists, or otherwise create any potential hazard to motorists, or uses admonitions such as "stop," "go," "slow," "danger," etc., which might be confused with traffic directional signals. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 8.03) Sec. 40-350. - Signs in the public right-of-way. No signs, including any overhang, shall be allowed within the public right-of-way, except public signs erected by or on behalf of a governmental body to post legal notices, identify public property, convey public information, or direct or regulate traffic, information signs of a public utility regarding its poles, lines, pipes, or facilities, or emergency warning signs erected by a governmental body, a public utility company or a contractor doing authorized or permitted work within the public right-of-way. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 8.04) Sec. 40-351. - Signs not requiring a permit. The following signs shall be exempt from the permit requirements of this article, provided that the signs erected or placed are located on property of the person who erects such signs or on property whose owner has given permission for such placement: (1) Traffic directional, warning, or information signs authorized or required by any public agency in accordance with a valid law, regulations, or chapter. (2) Official notices issued by a court, public agency, or officer. (3) Signs prohibiting or otherwise controlling trespassing upon particular premises, or indicating the private nature of a road, driveway or premises may be erected and maintained, provided that the area of any such sign shall not exceed two square feet. (4) Seasonal or holiday lights and decorations. (5) Signs not exceeding ten square feet in area giving information concerning the location or use of accessory off-street parking facilities or loading and unloading facilities. (6) One non-illuminated temporary construction project sign, political sign, or real estate sign offering property for sale, rent, or lease not exceeding six square feet in area in residential districts and 16 square feet in other than residential districts and located no less than 20 feet back from the street right-of-way line, unless attached to the front wall of a building for each 300 linear feet of road frontage of property involved. Such signs shall be removed when their temporary purpose has been served. (7) Signs advertising garage sales, provided they do not exceed four square feet in area, and are limited to only one sign posted on the premises of the sale. Such signs shall be posted no earlier than one week prior to the sale, and the posting is limited only to the duration of the sale. (8) Campaign posters placed on private property no more than 30 days prior to the first primary election of an election year or other special election, and are removed no more than 72 hours following the election which is the subject of the poster. (9) Any flag representing a federal or state governmental entity or political subdivision without limit. (10) Ornamental flags attached to a building and limited to one per principal structure. (11) Window signs displayed from inside a business provided that no more than 50 percent of the total window surface of each window with a sign visible from the outside is covered by the display, and the total area does not exceed 100 square feet. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 8.05) Sec. 40-352. - Temporary, spectacular, or special event signs. (a) Temporary, spectacular or special event signs are signs which are not permanently erected, affixed, or maintained on premises for a long period of time and that include: (1) Any piece or strip of cloth, paper, canvas, plastic or similar material affixed to the principal building or the curtilage thereof, on which a message, slogan, or emblem is painted, drawn, or otherwise projected, colored, or shaped for the purpose of advertising or drawing public attention; (2) Balloons; (3) Vehicles, trailers, and other mobile devices which are parked or placed in a stationary position and which have a sign mounted on the vehicle or are painted to display a message or otherwise act as a sign or attention-getting device; (4) Other attention-getting devices, but not including banners, fluttering ribbons, flags, or streamers, are considered temporary, special event or spectacular signs. (b) Temporary, special event, or spectacular signs may be issued a temporary sign permit that may allow the use of such a sign subject to the following requirements: (1) A temporary sign permit shall allow the use of a temporary, special event, or spectacular sign for a specified 30-day period. (2) The temporary, special event, or spectacular signs authorized are on-premises signs. (3) The maximum size for all temporary, special event, or spectacular signs under any one permit shall be 100 square feet. (4) Except as modified by this section, all signs authorized under a temporary sign permit must otherwise comply and not violate all other applicable regulations, conditions, and prohibitions set forth in this article. (5) No more than three permits for temporary signs shall be issued to any applicant in any calendar year. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 8.06) Sec. 40-353. - Number of on-site signs restricted in residential districts. In residential districts, no more than one on-site sign for each family residing on the premises, either indicating the name of the owner or occupant, or pertaining to a permitted nonresidential use will be allowed, provided such sign shall not exceed four square feet in area and shall not be illuminated in any manner, and shall not exceed six feet in height. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 8.07(A)) Sec. 40-354. - Limitations on group development and subdivision signs in residential districts. In residential districts, a permanent sign identifying a group development or a subdivision may be erected on each street frontage of the development, provided that such sign is constructed of brick, stone, masonry, wood, or equal architectural material and each sign does not exceed 32 square feet in area and eight feet in height. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 8.07(B)) Sec. 40-355. - Educational, religious, charitable, civic and fraternal sign restrictions. Signs of schools, colleges, churches, religious, charitable, civic, fraternal, political, or similar organizations shall be allowed, provided they relate exclusively to the institution erecting the same, do not exceed one sign per road frontage, and are limited to 32 square feet in area in residential districts and to 100 square feet in area in all other districts. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 8.07(C)) Sec. 40-356. - On-site signs in commercial, industrial and agricultural districts restricted. (a) In commercial, industrial, and agricultural districts, on-site signs for an individual establishment on an individual lot will be allowed, provided that wall signs in total do not exceed 64 square feet in area and no more than one self-standing sign per road frontage is allowed, provided that each such sign does not exceed 100 square feet in area, and any such signs are no closer than 100 feet from another self-standing sign. (b) In commercial, industrial, or agricultural districts, on-site signs for a shopping center or other group development shall be allowed, provided that: (1) There is only one common freestanding sign per road frontage not to exceed 150 square feet in area. (2) No individual establishment within the group development shall be allowed to have a separate freestanding sign. (3) Only one wall sign per entrance allotted to an individual establishment, or one wall sign per common entrance, will be allowed, provided that each sign does not exceed 64 square feet in area. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 8.07(D), (E)) Sec. 40-357. - Changeable copy signs. Changeable copy signs are permitted as an integral part of any sign which meets all other requirements of this article, provided that such signs will only be allowed as part of the original construction and erection or as part of a permitted significant alteration of a sign that complies with the specifications required herein and is an integral part of such sign. In addition, the changeable copy portion of a sign shall not exceed 50 percent of the total allowed sign area for that sign. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 8.07(F)) Sec. 40-358. - Minimum required wind resistance and setbacks; maximum height. All signs must be designed to withstand winds of 80 miles per hour. All signs are set back at least ten feet from any street right-of-way and at least 15 feet from any property line. No sign shall exceed 25 feet in height. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 8.07(G)—(I)) Secs. 40-359—40-389. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - MANUFACTURED HOMES AND HOME PARKS
Sec. 40-390. - Statement of purpose. The purpose of these regulations is to ensure the development of manufactured home parks which are not crowded and provide safe and sanitary living conditions for park occupants, and which contribute positively rather than negatively to the general character and appearance of the city and to the public health, safety, and welfare. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 5.00) Sec. 40-391. - Applicability of regulations. These regulations apply to manufactured home parks. A manufactured home park shall remain single ownership and may not be subdivided for sale of individual lots, unless all applicable regulations are met for such subdivision, including public street frontage and a minimum lot size of 15,000 square feet, among others. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 5.01) Sec. 40-392. - General development regulations and minimum standards. (a) The manufactured home park shall be no less than two acres in size and shall front upon a public street. (b) The manufactured home park shall be located on a well-drained site, properly graded to ensure positive drainage and freedom from stagnant pools of water. (c) A manufactured home park shall have a minimum four spaces prepared with all utilities in place prior to its approval for occupancy. (d) Each manufactured home space shall be connected to a public water and sewer system, if available. If not available, an approved and in-place water source and sewage disposal system as regulated by the state environmental protection division or the local health department, must be obtained and evidence of such provided, prior to approval of occupancy. (e) The manufactured home park shall front upon at least one publicly dedicated street, but no manufactured home spaces shall have direct access to a publicly dedicated street. (f) Each manufactured housing space and its parking area shall have direct access to the internal street system of the park. (g) Streets within a manufactured home park shall either be paved or graveled and shall be privately owned, operated, and maintained. Such private streets shall be well-drained, with a minimum width of driving surface of 14 feet for one-way and 24 feet for two-way streets, and with unobstructed access to a public street or highway. (h) Each manufactured home space shall be provided with a minimum of two off-street parking spaces. The side yard space of a manufactured home may not be used for the parking of motor vehicles. (i) The manufactured home park shall be so designed that manufactured homes (and recreational vehicles, if permitted) and their accessory structures shall be a minimum distance of 20 feet from adjoining property lines and spaces, 30 feet from internal park streets, and at least 40 feet from any publicly dedicated street. (j) Each manufactured home space shall provide a minimum area of 7,500 square feet for manufactured homes or 4,000 square feet for recreational vehicle stands with a maximum density of five manufactured home spaces or ten recreational vehicle stands per gross acre. (k) The internal street system within the park shall be lighted to provide safe, convenient access to all parts of the park during evening hours. (l) Each manufactured home space shall be provided an underground electrical power supply with a properly grounded, waterproofed electrical receptacle with a minimum rated capacity of 150 amperes. A properly sized over current device shall be installed as part of each power outlet. (m) A clearly visible property and street number designation or other appropriate numbering device properly identifying each manufactured home space shall be placed at a point no farther than 15 feet from the interior road system of the park, and such device shall be a minimum of six inches in height. (n) A planted buffer strip at least ten feet wide shall be provided along all boundaries of a manufactured home park, excepting only ingress and egress points. Such buffer strip shall be planted with evergreen trees or shrubs that grow at least eight feet tall and provide an effective visual screen within five years. Such plantings must be in accordance with all provisions of this chapter, and shall be maintained in a healthy, growing condition. (Ord. of 1-12-2009, § 5.02) Sec. 40-393. - Manufactured home standards. (a) Only those manufactured homes which can clearly demonstrate that they currently meet the federal department of housing and urban development standards for building construction shall be placed in any manufactured home park. (b) All manufactured homes placed in any manufactured home park shall have properly installed skirting materials manufactured for that purpose and appropriately matching the exterior of the manufactured home, or of materials, such as masonry, wood, concrete, or stucco, and workmanship approved by the city. (c) All manufactured homes shall be anchored with safety tie-downs as recommended by the manufacturer.
